revision.text:
'''Abraham Jacob Briloff''' (July 19, 1917 - Dec. 12, 2013) was an American accounting scholar and Professor of accounting at [[Baruch College]] in New York. He was known for his contributions to accountancy,<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/16/business/abraham-briloff-accounting-professor-dies-at-96.html?_r=0 Abraham Briloff, Accounting Professor, Dies at 96], The New York Times, December 15, 2013</ref><ref name="AHoF 2015">[http://fisher.osu.edu/departments/accounting-and-mis/the-accounting-hall-of-fame/membership-in-hall/abraham-jacob-briloff/ Abraham Jacob Briloff], The Accounting Hall of Fame. Accessed 2015-02-14.</ref> and also as the "most prominent accounting critic."<ref>Floyd Norris. "[https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/12/13/abe-briloff-an-accountant-who-saw-through-the-games/?_r=0 Abe Briloff, an Accountant Who Saw Through the Games]," ''economix.blogs.nytimes.com,'' Dec. 13, 2013. Accessed 2015-02-14.</ref>
== Biography == Born in Manhattan to Benjamin and Anna Briloff, Briloff obtained his BA in commerce at the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, now [[Baruch College]], in 1937. Later in 1965 he obtained his PhD in accountancy and taxation at the [[New York University]] with the thesis, entitled "The Effectiveness of Accounting Communication."
Briloff began his career in the final days of the [[Great Depression]] as high school teacher, teaching bookkeeping and stenography, and as assistant accountant in the accountancy firm of Apfel & Englander. In 1944 he became partner in that firm, and in 1951 started his own accountancy firm. In 1944 he also started lecturing accounting at the [[City College of New York]], where he became a full-time faculty member in 1965. In 1976 he was appointed Emanuel Saxe Distinguished Professor of Accountancy.<ref>[http://www.baruch.cuny.edu/news/AbrahamBriloffAccountingHallofFame.htm Abraham J. Briloff ('37, MSEd '41) Elected to Accounting Hall of Fame] at baruch.cuny.edu. June 5, 2014. Accessed 2015-02-14.</ref> He later started writing for the [[Barron's (newspaper)|Barron's Magazine]], a financial weekly.
Briloff was inducted into the [[Accounting Hall of Fame]] in 2014. Their argument was, that "for over half a century, he was the conscience of the accounting profession, challenging it to raise standards and to meet its obligations to society. Always motivated by the best interests of the accounting profession, he was respected by both supporters and targets of his criticism."<ref name="AHoF 2015"/>
== Selected publications == * Briloff, Abraham J. ''Effectiveness of Accounting Communication.'' (1967). * Briloff, Abraham J. ''Unaccountable Accounting.'' Harpercollins, 1972. * Briloff, Abraham J. ''More Debits than Credits.'' Harper and Row, New York, NY (1976). * Briloff, Abraham J. ''The Truth about Corporate Accounting.'' Harpercollins, 1981.
Articles, a selection: * Briloff, Abraham J. "Old myths and new realities in accountancy." ''[[Accounting Review]]'' (1966): 484-495. * Briloff, Abraham J. "Accountancy and society a covenant desecrated." ''[[Critical Perspectives on Accounting]]'' 1.1 (1990): 5-30. * Briloff, Abraham J. "Garbage in/garbage out: A critique of fraudulent financial reporting: 1987–1997 (the COSO report) and the SEC accounting regulatory process." ''Critical Perspectives on Accounting'' 12.2 (2001): 125-148.
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/16/business/abraham-briloff-accounting-professor-dies-at-96.html?_r=0 Abraham Briloff, Accounting Professor, Dies at 96], The New York Times, December 15, 2013 * [http://fisher.osu.edu/departments/accounting-and-mis/the-accounting-hall-of-fame/membership-in-hall/abraham-jacob-briloff/ Abraham Jacob Briloff], The Accounting Hall of Fame
{{Authority control}}

{{more citations needed|date=April 2015}} {{Business administration}}
'''Asset management''' refers to systematic approach to the governance and realization of value from the things that a group or entity is responsible for, over their whole life cycles. It may apply both to tangible [[asset]]s (physical objects such as buildings or equipment) and to intangible [[asset]]s (such as human capital, [[intellectual property]], [[goodwill (accounting)|goodwill]] and/or [[financial assets]]). Asset management is a systematic process of developing, operating, maintaining, upgrading, and disposing of assets in the most cost-effective manner (including all costs, risks and performance attributes).
The term is commonly used in the financial sector to describe people and companies who manage investments on behalf of others. Those include, for example, [[Investment management|investment managers]] that manage the assets of a [[pension fund]].
It is also increasingly used in both the business world and [[public infrastructure]] sectors to ensure a coordinated approach to the optimization of costs, risks, service/performance and sustainability.
The International Standard, [[ISO 55000]], provides a introduction and requirements specification for a management system for asset management.
==By Industry==
===Financial asset management=== The most common usage of the term "asset manager" refers to [[investment management]], the sector of the [[financial services]] industry that manages [[investment fund]]s and [[Security segregation|segregated client accounts]]. Asset management is part of a financial company which employs experts who manage money and handle the investments of clients. From studying the client's assets to planning and looking after the investments, all things are looked after by the asset managers and recommendations are provided based on the financial health of each client.
===Physical and Infrastructure asset management=== {{main article|Infrastructure asset management}} Infrastructure asset management is the combination of management, financial, economic, engineering, and other practices applied to physical assets with the objective of providing the best value level of service for the costs involved. It includes the management of the entire life cycle—including design, construction, commissioning, operating, maintaining, repairing, modifying, replacing and decommissioning/disposal—of physical and infrastructure assets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lgam.info/asset-management|title=Asset Management - LGAM Knowledge Base|author=|date=|website=www.lgam.info}}</ref> Operation and maintenance of assets in a constrained budget environment require a prioritization scheme. As a way of illustration, the recent development of [[renewable energy]] has seen the rise of effective asset managers involved in the management of solar systems (solar park, rooftops and windmills). These teams often collaborate with financial asset managers in order to offer [[turnkey]] solutions to investors. Infrastructure asset management became very important in most of the developed countries in the 21st century, since their infrastructure network was almost completed in the 20th century and they have to manage to operate and maintain them cost-effectively.<ref>Vanier, D. (2001) Why Industry Needs Asset Management Tools. ASCE Journal of Computing in Civil Engineering. Vol 15(1)</ref> [[Software asset management]] is one kind of infrastructure asset management.
The International Organization for Standardization published its management system standard for asset management in 2014.<ref>https://www.iso.org/news/2014/01/Ref1813.htm</ref>. The [[ISO 55000]] series provides terminology, requirements and guidance for implementing, maintaining and improving an effective asset management system.
* Physical asset management: the practice of managing the entire life cycle (design, construction, commissioning, operating, maintaining, repairing, modifying, replacing and decommissioning/disposal) of physical and infrastructure assets such as structures, production and service plant, power, water and waste treatment facilities, distribution networks, transport systems, buildings and other physical assets. The increasing availability of data from asset systems is allowing the principles of [[Total Cost of Ownership]] to be applied to facility management of an individual system, a building, or across a campus. Physical asset management is related to [[asset health management]]. *[[Infrastructure asset management]] expands on this theme in relation primarily to public sector, [[utilities]], property and transport systems. Additionally, Asset Management can refer to shaping the future interfaces between the human, built, and natural environments through collaborative and evidence-based decision processes *[[Fixed assets management]]: an accounting process that seeks to track fixed assets for the purposes of [[financial accounting]] *[[IT asset management]]: the set of business practices that join financial, contractual and inventory functions to support life cycle management and strategic decision making for the IT environment. This is also one of the processes defined within [[IT service management]] *[[Digital asset management]]: a form of electronic media content management that includes digital assets
===Enterprise asset management=== [[Enterprise asset management]] (EAM) systems are asset ''information'' systems that support the management of an organization's assets. An EAM includes an asset registry (inventory of assets and their attributes) combined with a [[computerized maintenance management system]] (CMMS) and other modules (such as inventory or materials management). Assets that are geographically distributed, interconnected or networked, are often also represented through the use of [[Geographic information system|geographic information systems (GIS)]].
GIS-centric asset registry standardizes data and improves interoperability, providing users the capability to reuse, coordinate, and share information in an efficient and effective manner . A GIS platform combined with information of both the "hard" and "soft" assets helps to remove the traditional silos of departmental functions. While the [[hard asset]]s are the typical physical assets or infrastructure assets, the soft assets might include permits, licenses, brands, patents, right-of-ways and other entitlements or valued items.
The EAM system is only one of the 'enables' to good asset management. Asset managers need to make informed decisions in order to fulfill their organizational goals, this requires good asset information but also leadership, clarity of strategic priorities, competencies, inter-departmental collaboration and communications, workforce and supply chain engagement, risk and change management systems, performance monitoring and continual improvement.
===Public asset management=== {{POV section|date=April 2014}} Public asset management, also called corporate{{Contradict-inline|reason=public opposite to corporate (private)|date=May 2017}} asset management, expands the definition of enterprise asset management (EAM) by incorporating the management of all things of value to a municipal [[jurisdiction]] and its citizens' expectations. An example in which public asset management is used is land-use development and planning.
==Intellectual and non-physical asset management== Increasingly both consumers and organizations use assets, e.g. software, music, books, etc. where the user's rights are constrained by a license agreement. An asset management system would identify the constraints upon such licenses, e.g. a time period. If, for example, one licenses software, often the license is for a given period of time. Adobe and Microsoft both offer time based software licenses. In both the corporate and consumer worlds, there is a distinction between software ownership and the updating of software. One may own a version of software, but not newer versions of the software. Cellular phones are often not updated by vendors, in an attempt to force purchase of newer hardware. Large companies such as Oracle, that license software to clients distinguish between the right to use and the right to received maintenance/support.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2491993,00.asp|title=The Best Asset Management Software of 2018|author=|date=|website=pcmag.com}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Asset management firm]] * [[IT asset management]] * [[List of asset management firms]] * [[P2P Asset Management]] * [[Robo-advisor]] * [[Software asset management]] * [[ISO 55000]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Baird, G. "Defining Public Asset Management for Municipal Water Utilities". ''Journal American Water Works Association'' May 2011, 103:5:30, www.awwa.org
==External links== * [https://committee.iso.org/tc251 ISO/TC 251 - ISO Asset Management Information] * [https://www.iso.org/standard/55088.html ISO page for ISO 55000] * [http://www.theiam.org/knowledge/ IAM page for introduction to Asset Management]

{{Infobox building | name = Atelier | status = Open | address = 635 West 42nd Street | location_country = United States | coordinates = {{coord|40|45|41.5|N|74|00|5.84|W|display=inline,title}} | start_date = 2004 | completion_date = 2007 | opened_date = 2007 | architect = [[Costas Kondylis]] | floor_count = 46 | map_type = Manhattan | building_type = Residential | architectural_style = Modernism | roof = {{convert|521|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} | structural_engineer = Rosenwasser/Grossman Consulting Engineers P.C. | location_city = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] }}
'''Atelier''' is a residential building [[condominium]] tower located in [[Midtown Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. The building stands at 521 ft (158.8 m) and includes 478 individual units spanning 46 floors.
== Building == The Atelier building is located at 635 West [[42nd Street (Manhattan)|42nd Street]] in [[Manhattan]], [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.veranda.com/luxury-lifestyle/news/a1518/go-inside-new-york-citys-most-expensive-condo/|title=Go Inside New York City's Most Expensive Condo|last=Alessio|first=Devin|date=2016-03-07|work=Veranda|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en-US}}</ref> It is part of several high-rise buildings (along with Sky and [[Silver Towers]]) built in the [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell's Kitchen]] neighborhood of [[Midtown Manhattan]] that have transformed the area between 11th and [[12th Avenue (Manhattan)|12th Avenue]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/hells-kitchen-is-heating-up-1468614756|title=Hell’s Kitchen Is Heating Up|last=Cary|first=Bill|date=2016-07-15|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://rew-online.com/2011/08/22/selling-secrets-the-marketing-directors-on-how-to-survive-boom-and-bust/|title=Selling secrets: the Marketing Directors on how to survive boom and bust|last=Grey|first=Liana|date=2011-08-22|work=Real Estate Weekly|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en-US}}</ref> At a height of 521 ft (158.8 m),<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=35184|title=Atelier, New York City|website=SkyscraperPage.com|access-date=2018-02-02}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.skyscrapercenter.com/building/atelier/3420|title=Atelier|website=The Skyscraper Center|access-date=2018-02-02}}</ref> Atelier looks over the Hudson River located a block away to the West.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/real-estate/midtown-condo-building-rooftop-ice-skating-rink-article-1.1987311|title=Midtown condo building getting rooftop ice-skating rink|last=Clarke|first=Katherine|date=2014-10-26|work=NY Daily News|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en}}</ref> The building stands 46-stories tall and contains a total of 478 individual units.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/29/realestate/29cov.html|title=A Frontier With a View on the Far West Side of Manhattan|last=Mooney|first=Jake|date=2010-08-27|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
The building's name comes from [[Atelier|the word for an artist's workshop]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://rew-online.com/2011/05/05/emperor-of-the-skyline/|title=Emperor of the skyline|last=Li|first=Roland|date=2011-05-05|work=Real Estate Weekly|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en-US}}</ref> The building features an art gallery on the ground floor and often holds exhibitions of artwork. The gallery is also visible from the street and includes the lobby of the building as part of its exhibit space. As of January 2009, it featured the works of graphic designer and New York-based artist [[Milton Glaser]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/04/realestate/04cov.html|title=The Come-Hither Lobby|last=Grynbaum|first=Michael M.|date=2009|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
In 2011, solar panels were installed on the roof of the building capable of generating five percent of the energy needs of the building.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/01/02/the-big-apple-takes-a-bite-out-of-solar-energy.html|title=The Big Apple takes a bite out of solar energy|last=Quick|first=Brad|date=2015-01-03|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-02-08}}</ref> As of 2013, solar panels were generating ten percent of the building's energy needs.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/21/realestate/in-search-of-a-trophy-at-any-cost.html|title=In Search of a Trophy, at Any Cost|last=Barrionuevo|first=Alexei|date=2013-04-18|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-08|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> In 2014, Atelier became one of the first buildings in New York to include an ice-skating rink on the roof of the building which was installed by Daniel Neiditch, president of the condo board who owns many units in the building.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/07/realestate/pools-golf-and-bowling-right-down-the-hall.html|title=Pools, Golf, and Bowling: Right Down the Hall|last=Hughes|first=C. J.|date=2014-12-05|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-08|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>The rooftop terrace is also the location of a private lounge open to residents of the building.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://observer.com/2013/10/heaven-and-hells-kitchen-atelier-audaciously-debuts-25-m-mega-condo-combo/|title=Heaven In Hell’s Kitchen? Atelier Mega Condo Combo Tries for an Audacious $25 M.|last=Velsey|first=Kim|date=2013-10-25|work=Observer|access-date=2018-02-08|language=en-US}}</ref> As of 2014, the building also has several other amenities such as access to a playground,<ref name=":5" /> a basketball court, and a tennis court.<ref name=":3" />
In 2016, Atelier promoted the most expensive planned condominium property in New York City. The penthouse property spanning the entire 45th floor of the building<ref name=":5" /> and including 10 bedrooms and 13 bathrooms was listed in 2016 at $85 million.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-most-extreme-condos-on-the-market-1456411729|title=The Most Extreme High-Rise Condos on the Market|last=Keates|first=Nancy|date=2016-02-25|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-02-08|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> It was to be created by combining nine units located on the top floor.<ref name=":4" /> The plan was to include such lavish amenities as a one-million-dollar [[yacht]], two [[Rolls-Royce Motor Cars|Rolls-Royce]] Phantoms, and a year's worth of "live-in butler services – as well as a private chef".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.veranda.com/luxury-lifestyle/news/a1518/go-inside-new-york-citys-most-expensive-condo/|title=Go Inside New York City's Most Expensive Condo|last=Alessio|first=Devin|date=2016-03-07|work=Veranda|access-date=2018-02-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeout.com/newyork/blog/new-yorks-most-expensive-condo-comes-with-some-pretty-insane-perks-030416|title=New York's most expensive condo comes with some pretty insane perks|last=Gleason|first=Will|date=2016-03-04|work=Time Out New York|access-date=2018-02-08|language=en}}</ref>
== History == Atelier was designed by [[Costas Kondylis]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/05/arts/design/05arch.html|title=Costas Kondylis - Architecture|last=Pogrebin|first=Robin|date=2007-02-05|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Construction on the building began in 2004 and was completed in 2007.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Atelier was part of the company's development project of [[Manhattan]]'s [[West Side (Manhattan)|West Side]] which included several buildings along [[11th Avenue (Manhattan)|11th Avenue]].<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://rew-online.com/2014/08/06/moinian-secures-539m-to-build-west-side-condo/|title=Moinian secures $539M to build west side rental|date=2014-08-06|work=Real Estate Weekly|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en-US}}</ref> The building has been a popular destination for celebrities including [[Deborah Cox]], [[Brendan Fraser]], [[Lindsay Lohan]], [[Mekhi Phifer]], and [[Dania Ramirez]], some of whom have used it for brief stays in New York while performing on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://therealdeal.com/2013/05/06/atelier-signs-broadway-star-deborah-cox-nets-jerry-stackhouse-as-tenants/|title=Atelier signs Broadway star Deborah Cox, Nets’ Jerry Stackhouse as tenants|last=Kaplan|first=Hayley|date=2013-05-06|work=The Real Deal New York|access-date=2018-02-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://therealdeal.com/2016/04/26/michael-douglas-is-apartment-shopping-for-his-in-laws/|title=Michael Douglas is apartment shopping for his in-laws|last=Clarke|first=Katherine|date=2016-04-26|work=The Real Deal New York|access-date=2018-02-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://therealdeal.com/2011/02/10/atelier-draws-celebs-dane-cook-brendan-fraser-check-out-pads-while-dania-ramirez-rents/|title=Atelier draws celebs: Dane Cook, Brendan Fraser look while Dania Ramirez rents|last=Taylor|first=Candace|date=2011-02-10|work=The Real Deal New York|access-date=2018-02-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/real-estate/thy-neighbor-amenity-rich-buildings-prove-life-city-doesn-lonely-article-1.404015|title=Know thy neighbor: Amenity-rich buildings offer social life|last=Sloan|first=Carrie|date=2009-09-25|work=NY Daily News|access-date=2018-02-08|language=en}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Condominiums and housing cooperatives in Manhattan]] [[Category:Residential buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Residential skyscrapers in Manhattan]] [[Category:Residential buildings completed in 2007]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]]

{{BLP sources|date=January 2010}} '''Atilano Cordero Badillo''' (born c. 1943 in [[Moca, Puerto Rico]]) is a [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] entrepreneur and [[supermarket]] owner.
==Career== In 1967 he founded [[Supermercados Grande]] where he remains as President and he is also President of Empresas Cordero Badillo.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.puertorico-herald.org/issues/vol4n17/CBOneStop-en.html |title=One-Stop Shopping |date=April 27, 2000 |publisher=''Puerto Rico Herald'' |accessdate=January 11, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104112544/http://puertorico-herald.org/issues/vol4n17/CBOneStop-en.html |archivedate=January 4, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Cordero Badillo has developed Food Price stores in Puerto Rico which are based on the warehouse model of food sales.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.puertorico-herald.org/issues/2001/vol5n47/CBFoodPrice-en.html |title=Food Price To Anchor Outlet Mall, Add Two Stores |date=November 22, 2001 |publisher=''Puerto Rico Herald'' |accessdate=January 11, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104043136/http://puertorico-herald.org/issues/2001/vol5n47/CBFoodPrice-en.html |archivedate=January 4, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Cordero Badillo is President of the Chamber of the Food Marketing & Distribution Industry (MIDA)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.puertorico-herald.org/issues/2003/vol7n34/CBMida-en.html |title=MIDA Gets Serious About Legislative Reform |date=August 21, 2003 |publisher=''Puerto Rico Herald'' |accessdate=January 11, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104160609/http://puertorico-herald.org/issues/2003/vol7n34/CBMida-en.html |archivedate=January 4, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Through his career he has won numerous awards, and he belongs to the Top Business Leaders association of Puerto Rico's Hall of Fame. He was named president of that organization from 1986 to 1990.
==See also== *[[List of famous Puerto Ricans]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Badillo, Atilano Cordero}} [[Category:1943 births|Cordero Badillo, Atilano]] [[Category:American businesspeople in retailing]] [[Category:Living people|Cordero Badillo, Atilano]] [[Category:People from Moca, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Puerto Rican businesspeople]]

{{Infobox military person | name = Bertram Meryl (Bert) Hoffmeister | image = Bert Hoffmeister.jpg | caption = Major-General B.M. Hoffmeister, General Officer Commanding [[5th Canadian (Armoured) Division|5th Canadian Armoured Division]], in the turret of the [[M4 Sherman|Sherman tank]] "Vancouver" near Castrocielo, 23 May 1944 | unit = [[File:1 Canadian Infantry Division patch.png|30px]][[1st Canadian Division]]
[[File:5 Canadian Armoured Division patch.png|30px]][[5th Canadian Division]]
Canadian Army Pacific Force | nickname = | birth_date = May 15, 1907 | death_date =December 4, 1999 (age 92) | birth_place = [[Vancouver]], British Columbia, Canada | death_place = | placeofburial= | placeofburial_label= | allegiance = Canadian | branch = Canadian Active Service Force | rank = [[Major-general#Canada|Major General]] | serviceyears = 1939-1945 | battles = '''[[World War II]]''' *[[Battle of Sicily]] *[[Italian Campaign (World War II)|Italian Campaign]] *[[Moro River Campaign|Moro River]] *[[Battle of Ortona]] *[[Operation Diadem|Liri Valley]] *[[Gothic Line]] *[[Battle of Rimini (1944)|Battle of Rimini]] *[[Liberation of Arnhem]] *[[North West Europe Campaign]] |awards = [[Order of Canada|Officer of the Order of Canada]]
[[Order of the Bath|Companion of the Order of the Bath]]
[[Order of the British Empire|Commander of the Order of the British Empire]]
[[Distinguished Service Order|Companion of the Distinguished Order]] | relations = | laterwork = }} [[Major-general#Canada|Major General]] '''Bertram Meryl "Bert" Hoffmeister''' {{postnominals|country=CAN|OC|CB|CBE|DSO*|ED}} (15 May 1907 – 4 December 1999) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[Canadian Army|Army]] officer, businessman, and conservationist. ==Biography== [[File:Hoffmeister e010786144-v8.jpg|thumb|left|Bert Hoffmeister]] Born in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] to parents Louis and Flora, he was a sales manager with the Canadian White Pine Co. Ltd. in Vancouver. He enlisted with the [[Non-Permanent Active Militia]] (NPAM, the Canadian Army Reserve Force) in 1927. He was promoted [[Captain (Canadian army and air force)|captain]] in 1934. After he was promoted to major, in 1939, he was made officer commanding a company of the [[The Seaforth Highlanders of Canada|Seaforth Highlanders of Canada]] who went to England in 1939. He attended the Canadian Junior War Staff courses at the [[Royal Military College of Canada]] in [[Kingston, Ontario]]. In 1942, he was promoted to [[lieutenant colonel]]. In 1943, he was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] while [[Allied invasion of Sicily|fighting in Sicily]].[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/36232/supplements/4847] He received a bar to the DSO the following year[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/36668/supplements/3924] In October 1943, promoted to [[brigadier general]], he was named commanding officer of the 2nd Canadian Infantry Brigade, who fought in the [[Italian Campaign (World War II)|Italian Campaign]]. In March 1944, he was promoted to major general and made general officer commanding the [[5th Canadian Armoured Division]]. After VE-Day, he was made general officer commanding the [[6th Canadian Infantry Division|6th Canadian Division]] (Canadian Army Pacific Force) which disbanded after the atomic bombings of Japan. Hoffmeister retired from active service in September 1945. That same year, he was made a Grand Officer in the [[Order of Orange Nassau]] with swords as well as a Companion of the [[Order of the Bath]] [http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/37161/supplements/3490] and a Commander of the [[Order of the British Empire]].[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/36785/supplements/5129] In 1947, he was made a Commander of the [[Legion of Merit]]. After the war, in 1949 he became president of [[MacMillan Bloedel Limited]] and was its chairman from 1956 to 1958. From 1958 to 1961, he was British Columbia's agent general in London. From 1961 to 1968, he was chairman of the Council of Forest Industries of British Columbia, an association for the British Columbia interior forest industry. From 1971 to 1991 he was the founding chairman of the Nature Trust of British Columbia, a non-profit land conservation organization. In 1982, he was made an Officer of the [[Order of Canada]], Canada's highest civilian honour. ==References== {{reflist}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.junobeach.org/e/3/can-pep-can-hoffmeister-e.htm|title=Major-General B.M. Hoffmeister|work=Juno Beach Centre|accessdate=August 10, 2005 }} *{{cite web|url=http://www.utpress.utoronto.ca/cgi-bin/cw2w3.cgi?p=hiruki&t=74246&d=2258|title=Canadian Who's Who 1997 entry|work=[[University of Toronto Press]]}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *{{cite book|title=The Soldiers' General: Bert Hoffmeister at War|author=Douglas E. Delaney|publisher=University of British Columbia Press|isbn=0-7748-1149-8|year=2006}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.okmilmuseum.ca/okmilmuseumbiohoffmeister.htm|title=Military Biography MGen Bert Hoffmeister|work=Okanagan Military Museum|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130812101917/http://www.okmilmuseum.ca/okmilmuseumbiohoffmeister.htm|archivedate=2013-08-12|df=}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hoffmeister, Bert}} [[Category:1907 births]] [[Category:1999 deaths]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Vancouver]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Canadian generals]] [[Category:Canadian military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Canadian Commanders of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Canadian Companions of the Distinguished Service Order]] [[Category:Canadian conservationists]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of Canada]] [[Category:Commanders of the Legion of Merit]] [[Category:Grand Officers of the Order of Orange-Nassau]] [[Category:Royal Military College of Canada alumni]]

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Brian Hatfield |image = Brian Hatfield.jpeg |image_size = 200px |caption = |image name = |state_senate = Washington |district = 19th |term_start = November 17, 2006 |term_end = |predecessor = |succecessor = |state_house1 = Washington |district1 = 19th |term_start1 = 1994 |term_end1 = 2004 |predecessor1 = |succecessor1 = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1966|7|8}} |birth_place = [[Aberdeen, Washington]] |alma_mater = [[Washington State University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
[[Grays Harbor College]] ([[Associate degree|A.A.]] |profession = |spouse = |children = |residence = |religion = |website = [http://sdc.wastateleg.org/hatfield/ Official] }} '''Brian Hatfield''' (born July 8, 1966) served in the [[Washington State Senate]] and the [[Washington State House of Representatives]], representing the 19th Legislative District, a district that includes [[Cowlitz County, Washington|Cowlitz]], [[Grays Harbor County, Washington|Grays Harbor]], [[Pacific County, Washington|Pacific]], [[Lewis County, Washington|Lewis]] and [[Wahkiakum County, Washington|Wahkiakum]] Counties. After serving ten years in the [[Washington State House of Representatives]](1994–2004), Hatfield resigned in 2004 to work full-time for [[Lieutenant Governor of Washington|Lieutenant Governor]] [[Brad Owen]]. He was appointed in 2006 to the Senate to replace [[Mark Doumit]]. He received 73.89% of the vote in the 2007 special election and was re-elected, without opposition, to a four-year term in 2008. In the Senate, Hatfield chaired the [[Agriculture, Water & Rural Economic Development Committee]] and serves on the Economic Development, Trade & Innovation Committee and the Ways & Means Committee. On September 1, 2015, Hatfield resigned to serve as Washington Governor [[Jay Inslee|Jay Inslee’s]] sector lead for rural economic development.http://www.chinookobserver.com/co/local-news/20150901/hatfield-resignation-sets-off-succession-scramble ==References== ==External links== *https://web.archive.org/web/20100729084103/http://www.senatedemocrats.wa.gov/senators/hatfield/biography.htm *http://senatedemocrats.wa.gov/senators/hatfield/ *http://www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=21828 *http://vote.wa.gov/elections/WEI/ResultsByCounty.aspx?RaceID=283&CountyCode=%20&ElectionID=0&RaceTypeCode=O{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{Washington State Senators}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hatfield, Brian}} [[Category:Washington (state) state senators]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hatfield family]] [[Category:1966 births]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox project | name = CORE (COnnecting REpositories) | logo = Core.png | website = {{URL|https://core.ac.uk/}} | commercial = No | type = Open Access, Repositories, Harvesting | location = [[Open University]] | country = United Kingdom | key_people = [[Petr Knoth]] }}
'''CORE''' (COnnecting REpositories) is a service provided by the [[Knowledge Media Institute]], based at [[The Open University]], [[United Kingdom]]. The goal of the project is to aggregate all [[open access]] content distributed across different systems, such as [[Institutional repository|repositories]] and [[open access journal]]s, enrich this content using [[text mining]] and [[data mining]], and provide free access to it through a set of services.<ref>{{cite web| title = OU’s full text search system makes huge leaps in widening access to academic papers| url = http://www3.open.ac.uk/media/fullstory.aspx?id=24452| date = 24 October 2012| accessdate = 19 December 2014 }}</ref> The CORE project also aims to promote open access to scholarly outputs. It fully supports the [[taxpayer]]'s entitlement to the research they have funded and facilitates the wide dissemination of the [[open access]] content. CORE works closely with [[Digital Library|digital libraries]] and [[Institutional repository|institutional repositories]].
Based on the open access fundamental principles, as they were described in the [[Budapest Open Access Initiative]], the open access content not only must be openly available to download and read, but it must also allow its reuse, both by humans and machines. As a result, there was a need to exploit the content reuse, which could be made possible with the implementation of a technical infrastructure. Thus the CORE project started with the goal of connecting [[metadata]] and full-text outputs offering, via the content aggregation, value-added services, and opening new opportunities in the research process.
Currently there are existing commercial academic search systems, such as [[Google Scholar]], which provide search and access level services, but do not support programmable machine access to the content, for example with the use of an [[Application programming interface|API]] or data dumps. This limits the further reuse of the open access content, for example, with regards to [[Text mining|text and data mining]]. Taking into consideration that there are three access levels to content: 1. access at the granularity of papers, 2. analytical access and granularity of collections and 3. programmable machine access to data<ref>{{Citation| last = Knoth| first = Petr | title = CORE: Three Access Levels to Underpin Open Access | journal = D-Lib Magazine| url = http://www.dlib.org/dlib/november12/knoth/11knoth.html| volume = 1 | number = 11/12 | date = December 2012 }}</ref> the programmable machine access is the main feature that distinguishes CORE from [[Google Scholar]] and [[Microsoft Academic Search]].
==History== The first version of CORE was created in 2011 by [[Petr Knoth]] with the aim to make it easier to access and [[text mining|text mine]] very large amounts of research publications.<ref>{{cite web| title = OUs full text search system makes huge leaps in widening access to academic papers| url = http://news.kmi.open.ac.uk/rostra/news.php?r=11&t=2&id=18463=KMi| date = 24 October 2012| accessdate = 19 December 2014}}</ref> The value of the aggregation was first demonstrated by developing a [[recommender system|content recommendation system]] for research papers, following the ideas of literature-based discovery introduced by [[Don R. Swanson]]. Since its start, CORE has received financial support from a range of funders including [[Jisc]] and the [[European Commission]]. Although CORE aggregates from across the world, it has the status of the UK's national aggregator of [[open access]] content, aggregating [[metadata]] and full-text outputs from both UK publishers' databases as well as institutional and subject repositories.<ref>{{cite web| title = CORE melds UK repositories| newspaper= Times of Higher Education | url = http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/417751.article| date = 13 October 2011| accessdate = 11 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title = UK’s first open access full-text search engine to aid research| publisher=The Research Centre | url = http://www.theresearchcentre.co.uk/feedstory/uk-s-open-access-full-text-search-engine-aid-research| date = 3 October 2011| accessdate = 19 December 2014}}</ref> The service operates as a one step search tool for UK's [[open access]] research outputs, facilitating easy discoverability, use and reuse. The importance of the service has been widely recognised by [[Jisc]], which suggested that CORE should preserve the required resources to sustain its operation and explore an international sustainability model.<ref>{{Citation | first = Neil | last = Jacobs | first2 = Nicky| last2 = Ferguson | title = Bringing the UK's open access research together: Barriers on the Berlin road to open access| year = 2014| publisher= Jisc | url = http://repository.jisc.ac.uk/5570/1/JISC_REPORT_open_mirror_090514_FINAL_WEB.pdf }}</ref> CORE is now one of the Repository Shared Services projects, along with [[SHERPA (organisation)|Sherpa Services]],<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.sherpa.ac.uk/| title= SHERPA Services | accessdate = 20 January 2015}}</ref> IRUS-UK,<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.irus.mimas.ac.uk/| title= IRUS UK| accessdate = 20 January 2015}}</ref> Jisc Publications Router<ref>{{cite web| url = http://broker.edina.ac.uk/| title = Jisc Publications Router| accessdate = 20 January 2015}}</ref> and [[OpenDOAR]].
==Programmable access to CORE data== CORE data can be accessed through an [[API]] or downloaded as a pre-processed and semantically enriched [https://core.ac.uk/services data dump].
==Searching CORE== CORE provides searchable access to a collection of over 125 millions of [[open access]] harvested research outputs. All outputs can be accessed and downloaded free of cost and have limited re-use restrictions. One can search the CORE content using a [[faceted search]]. CORE also provides a cross-repository content [[Recommender system|recommendation system]] based on full-texts. The collection of the harvested outputs is available either by looking at the latest additions<ref>{{cite web| url= http://core.kmi.open.ac.uk/browse/latest| title= CORE Latest Additions| accessdate = 20 January 2015}}</ref> or by browsing<ref>{{cite web| url = http://core.kmi.open.ac.uk/browse| title= CORE Browsing | accessdate = 20 January 2015}}</ref> the collection at the date of harvesting. The CORE search engine has been selected as one of the top 10 search engines<ref>{{cite web| title = Ten Search Engines for researchers that go beyond Google| series= Jisc Inform| url = http://www.jisc.ac.uk/inform/inform37/SearchingBeyondGoogle.html| date = Summer 2013 | accessdate = 17 November 2014 }}</ref> for open access research, facilitating access to academic papers.<ref>{{cite web | title = OU widens access to academic papers| url = http://www.openuniversity.edu/news-blog/news/ou-widens-access-to-academic-papers| accessdate = 17 November 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last = Else | first = Holly | title = ‘Dismal’ start for Access to Research initiative | newspaper = Times Higher Education | date = 14 August 2014 | url = http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/news/dismal-start-for-access-to-research-initiative/2015157.article| accessdate = 15 November 2014}}</ref> CORE ranks second among the most useful databases of searching electronic [[thesis]] and dissertations (ETDs).<ref>{{cite web| title = Top 100 Thesis and Dissertations on the Web| publisher= OnlinePhDProgram | url = http://onlinephdprogram.org/thesis-dissertation/| accessdate = 17 November 2014 }}</ref>
==Analytical use of CORE data== The availability of data aggregated and enriched by CORE provides opportunities for the development of new analytical services for research literature. These can be used, for example, to monitor growth and trends in research, validate compliance with [[open access mandate]]s and to develop new automatic metrics for evaluating research excellence.
==Applications== CORE offers eight applications: *CORE API, provides an access point for those who want to develop applications making use of CORE's large collection of Open Access content. <ref>{{cite web|url= https://core.ac.uk/services#api| title= CORE API|accessdate = 6 March 2018}}</ref> *CORE Dataset, enables the accessibility of the data aggregated from repositories by CORE and allows their further manipulation.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://core.ac.uk/services#dataset | title= CORE Dataset|accessdate = 6 March 2018}}</ref> *CORE Recommender, can link the institutional repository with the CORE service and it will recommend semantically related resources.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://core.ac.uk/services#recommender| title= CORE Recommender|accessdate = 6 March 2018}}</ref> *CORE Repository Dashboard, is a tool designed specifically for repository managers or research output administrators. The aim of the Repository Dashboard is to provide control over the aggregated content and help in the management and validation of the repository collections and services. <ref>{{cite web|url= https://core.ac.uk/services#dashboard | title= CORE Repository Dashboard|accessdate = 6 March 2018}}</ref> *CORE Analytics Dashboard, helps institutions to understand and monitor the impact of their research.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://core.ac.uk/services#dashboard | title= CORE Analytics Dashboard|accessdate = 6 March 2018}}</ref> * CORE Search, enables users to search and access research papers via a faceted search interface. <ref>{{cite web|url= https://core.ac.uk/| title= CORE Search|accessdate = 6 March 2018}}</ref> * CORE Publisher Connector, is a software providing seamless access to Gold and [[Hybrid open access journal |Hybrid Gold Open Access articles]] aggregated from non-standard systems of major publishers. Data is exposed via the ResourceSync protocol. <ref>{{cite web|url= https://core.ac.uk/services#connector| title= CORE Publisher Connector|accessdate = 6 March 2018}}</ref> * CORE SDKs, provide seamless access to our content for programmers. The CORE SDK R is freely available and it is mainly community led. The aim is to maximise the productivity and data analysis, prototyping and effortless migration.
==See also== * [[Institutional Repository]] * [[Open Access Button]] * [[SHERPA (organisation)|SHERPA]] * [[Directory of Open Access Journals]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * {{citation |title= CORE becomes the world’s largest aggregator |date= 1 June 2018 |url=https://scholarlycommunications.jiscinvolve.org/wp/2018/06/01/core-becomes-the-worlds-largest-aggregator/ |work=Jisc scholarly communications |location=UK }}
== External links == * {{official website|https://core.ac.uk/}}

{{Chinese name|[[Zheng (surname)|Cheng]]}} {{Infobox person | name = Cheng Yu-tung
[[Grand Bauhinia Medal|GBM]] | image = | birth_date = {{birth date|1925|8|26|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Shunde]], [[Guangdong]], [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2016|9|29|1925|8|26|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Hong Kong]] | spouse = Chow Tsui-ying (m.1943) | children = 4 | relations = [[Chow Chi Yuen|Chow Chi-yuen]] (father-in-law), [[Henry Cheng|Henry Kar-shun Cheng]] (son) [[Adrian Cheng]] Chi-kong (grandson) | networth = {{decrease}} US$16.6 billion (February 2016){{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/cheng-yu-tung/|title=The World's Billionaires|publisher=Forbes Media, LLC|access-date=1 October 2016}} }} '''Cheng Yu-tung''' [[Grand Bauhinia Medal|GBM]] ({{zh|t=鄭裕彤|s=郑裕彤|p=Zhèng Yùtóng|sl=Jeng6 Yue6 Tung4}}; 8 August 1925 – 29 September 2016) was a [[Hong Kong]] billionaire with extensive property investment, development and service businesses, hotels, infrastructure, jewellery retailing and transportation interests in Hong Kong, [[Macau]], United States, Australia and other areas. He was considered to be Hong Kong's third richest man at the time of his death.{{cite web|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Life-Arts/Milestone/Hong-Kong-billionaire-Cheng-Yu-tung-dies-at-91 |title=Hong Kong billionaire Cheng Yu-tung dies at 91 |publisher=Asia Nikkei}} ==Early life== Cheng was born in rural [[Shunde District]] in [[Guangdong]], the son of a tailor, and fled to [[Macau]] in 1940, ahead of the advancing Japanese occupation force. The goldsmith owner of the Chow Tai Fook store there took him on as an apprentice and he eventually married the boss's daughter. They moved to Hong Kong in 1946 and opened the company’s first store there.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/cheng-yu-tung-hong-kong-jewelry-real-estate-tycoon-dies-1475239893|title=Cheng Yu-tung, Hong Kong Jewelry, Real Estate Tycoon, Dies|last1=Chow|first1=Jason|last2=Fong|first2=Dominique|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=30 September 2016|access-date=1 October 2016}} == Business career == He founded and owned [[Chow Tai Fook Enterprises]], a conglomerate which operates the Sheraton Marina hotel and controls the publicly listed property developer [[New World Development|New World group]], which Cheng founded in 1970. Cheng’s wealth originated from his jewellery business, Chow Tai Fook.Forbes [https://www.forbes.com/lists/2011/82/hongkong-billionaires-11_Cheng-Yu-tung_NB1U.html "#4 Cheng Yu-tung"], ''Forbes'' Cheng’s grandson, [[Adrian Cheng|Adrian Cheng Chi-kong]], is set to inherit part of [[Chow Tai Fook]] and the Hong Kong-listed [[New World Development|New World group]], active in property and infrastructure.Alex Frew McMillan [https://www.cnbc.com/id/44899567 "Still in Control, Hong Kong Property Tycoons Face a Younger Generation"], ''CNBC'', 24 October 2011 He also had interests in [[Shun Tak Holdings]], and Macau casino operator [[Sociedade de Turismo e Diversoes de Macau]], owned by [[Stanley Ho]]. Cheng was a one-time real-estate investment partner of [[Donald Trump]]. Shortly before his death, Forbes listed him 58th wealthiest in the world and 3rd in Hong Kong with US$16.6 billion, and was at one time listed by Bloomberg as high as 34th.{{cite web |url=http://topics.bloomberg.com/bloomberg-billionaires-index/ |title=Bloomberg Billionaires Index |publisher=Bloomberg LP |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121214085457/http://topics.bloomberg.com/bloomberg-billionaires-index/ |archivedate=2012-12-14 |df= }}[http://hongkong.coconuts.co/2016/09/30/hong-kong-billionaire-tycoon-cheng-yu-tung-dies-aged-91 Hong Kong billionaire tycoon Cheng Yu-tung dies aged 91], Coconuts, 30 September 2016 Cheng also served on the board of [[Hang Seng Bank]], Hong Kong's third-largest bank. He represented the Kingdom of [[Bhutan]] in Hong Kong, serving as the honorary consul for the country. == Personal life == In 1943, Cheng married Chow Tsui-ying, the daughter of Chow Chi-yuen. In 1946, Cheng and his family moved to Hong Kong. Cheng had four children, Henry Cheng, Peter Cheng, Amy Cheng, and Lai-ha Cheng. Cheng's eldest son [[Henry Cheng]] (b.1946) is chairman of [[New World Development]] and related businesses.[http://www.china.org.cn/top10/2013-04/28/content_28686333_7.htm Top 10 richest Chinese in the world] ===Death=== Cheng spent the last four years of his life in bed after suffering a brain haemorrhage in 2012 and undergoing a major operation. Cheng was unconscious before he died.On September 26, 2016, Cheng died in Hong Kong. He was 91.{{cite web |URL=https://www.nationaljeweler.com/majors/market-developments/4728-the-king-of-jewelry-in-asia-dead-at-91 |title=The King of Jewelry in Asia Dead at 91 |publisher=NationalJewler.com |accessdate=November 28, 2018}} == See also == * [[Chow Chi-yuen]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.inq7.net/nwsbrk/2004/apr/26/nbk_5-1.htm Newsbreak] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130520144706/http://www.nwd.com.hk/html/eng/index.aspx%23 Corporate profile] *[https://www.forbes.com/finance/lists/10/2004/LIR.jhtml?passListId=10&passYear=2004&passListType=Person&uniqueId=NB1U&datatype=Person Forbes] listing *[http://www.nwd.com.hk/ New Word Development Company] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060702220516/http://www.shuntakgroup.com/ Shun Tak Holdings] {{s-start}} {{s-bus}} {{s-bef|before=[[Deacon Chiu]]}} {{s-ttl|title = Chairman of the [[Asia Television]] |years = 1989–1990}} {{s-aft|after=[[Wong Po-yan]]}} {{end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cheng, Yu-tung}} [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:Hong Kong billionaires]] [[Category:Hong Kong businesspeople]] [[Category:New World Development people| ]] [[Category:People from Foshan]] [[Category:Hong Kong financial businesspeople]] [[Category:Recipients of the Grand Bauhinia Medal]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Guangdong]] [[Category:Hong Kong BLCC members]] [[Category:Hong Kong Affairs Advisors]] [[Category:Members of the Selection Committee of Hong Kong]] {{HongKong-business-bio-stub}}

revision.comment: No longer an orphaned article
revision.text:
'''Demographic marketers''' use [[demographics]] in [[marketing research]], and the assessment of the changing trends of [[consumer behavior]]. Demographics can be called a science and demographic marketers can be called scientists. A demographic is used to describe individuals who are from a particular area. It can also be used to describe individuals who would rely on purchasing a particular product or service. Using demographics, a [[marketing manager]] can try to grasp what certain people think and what they are willing to buy.
By understanding how various characteristics of the population reflect their tastes, demographic marketers get an idea of the probability of the sales returns of a launched product in a given area. For any type of business, knowing who the [[customers]] are most likely to be through [[demographic analysis]] will make it easier to market effectively.
==External links== * [http://www.buydemographics.com Demographics Reports]
[[Category:Demographics]] [[Category:Market research]] [[Category:Business occupations]] [[Category:Science occupations]]

revision.text:
'''Sir Garet ‘Tiger’ Orlanda Finlayson''' [[OBE]] (born 4 August 1937{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}} in [[Long Bay Cay]], [[Andros, Bahamas|Andros]]) is a [[The Bahamas|Bahamian]] [[business magnate]].
The son of a [[tailor]], Finlayson, is the most successful black businessman in the [[Bahamas]]. Finlayson owns more than half the businesses on Bay Street, the Bahamas’ leading shopping street.<ref name=bio>[http://www.thenassauguardian.com/business/355178594683198.php Garet 'Tiger' Finlayson: Outstanding Black Bahamian Businessman Up Close and Personal, Nassau Guardian]</ref> Previously, Bay Street was wholly owned by white business merchants known as the [[Bay Street Boys]].
Finlayson owns leading Bahamian businesses Solomon Mines (luxury retail goods), Burns House and Butler & Sands ([[liquor store]]s). Over the years, Finlayson’s business concerns have included [[car dealerships]], [[hotels]], and [[furniture]], office products and [[restaurant]] businesses.<ref name=bio />
Finlayson’s recent acquisition of Solomon Mines, however, has been reportedly less than successful with the closing of four of 11 Bay Street shops,<ref name="tamed">[http://www.bahamasb2b.com/news/story.php?title=Tiger-Tamed-on-Bay-Street-1 Tiger Tamed on Bay Street, bahamasb2b.com]</ref> coinciding with a downturn in the street's fortunes.
A [[philanthropist]], Finlayson has donated millions of dollars in [[scholarships]], to allow young people to attend university, something Finlayson himself never did.<ref name=bio />
In 1999, Finlayson was made an [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) for services to the economic growth and development of the Bahamas.<ref name="obe">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/special_report/1999/06/99/queens_birthday_honours/366655.stm Commonwealth Honours, BBC News Online]</ref>
Finlayson is married to wife Rowena Frances Finlayson [née Rolle], with whom he has four children: Tanya Finlayson-Tynes,<ref name="tynes">[http://www.bahamasuncensored.com/nov03.htm#TIGER%92S%20DAUGHTER%20GETS BahamasUncensored.com November 2003]</ref> Rae Finlayson, Nikki Finlayson-Boeuf,<ref name="tamed"/> and Mark Finlayson.<ref name="bio"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.samanacollege.com/garet.html Garet Tiger Finlayson] at Samana College website
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Finlayson, Garet Tiger}} [[Category:Bahamian businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:People from South Andros]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of the British Empire]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} '''Sir Guy Fairfax''' (died 1495), was an [[Judge#England and Wales|English judge]].
Fairfax was of a [[Yorkshire]] family, and third son of Richard Fairfax of Walton,<ref>There are two places in Yorkshire called [[Walton (disambiguation)|Walton]]{{snd}}[[Walton, Leeds]] and [[Walton, Wakefield]]. The latter of those places was mentioned in the [[Domesday Book]]; and is the site of [[Walton Hall, West Yorkshire|Walton Hall]], a stately home built on the site of a former moated mediaeval hall. That is suggestive but not decisive evidence of where Thomas Fairfax lived.</ref> by his wife, Anastasia, daughter of John Carthorpe. He is mentioned<ref>Rot. Parl. iv. 164</ref> in 1421 as seised of the manor of [[Hameldene]], being then very young. From his father he inherited the manor of [[Steeton, West Yorkshire|Steeton]] in Yorkshire, where he built a castle. At first he seems to have been occupied with purely local business. He was in the commission of array for the [[West Riding of Yorkshire|West Riding]] in 1435, and in 1460 was commissioned to inquire what lands there were in that riding belonging to [[Richard Plantagenet, 3rd Duke of York|Richard, duke of York]], who had been attainted in the previous [[Parliament of England|parliament]].
One of his colleagues was Sir William Plumpton, whose counsel he afterwards was in 1469. He first appears in the year-books in [[Michaelmas]] 1463 as a [[Serjeant-at-law|serjeant]] and member of [[Gray's Inn]]. On 28 April 1468 he was appointed [[Serjeant-at-law#King's Serjeants|King's serjeant]], and in 1476 became [[Recorder (judge)|Recorder]] of [[York]]. He was raised to a judgeship of the [[Court of King's Bench (England)|King's bench]] and is first mentioned as a judge in [[Trinity term]] (around mid April to end of June) 1477. In this office he won an honourable reputation, and on 8 October 1482 he received a grant of a hundred [[Merk (coin)|merks]] yearly in addition to his salary. He was continued in his judgeship on each subsequent [[Demise of the Crown]], and under [[Edward V of England|Edward V]] became [[chief justice]] of [[Lancaster, Lancashire|Lancaster]].<ref>(Grants of Edward V, 6)</ref>
He died in 1495. By his wife, Margaret, a daughter of Sir [[William Ryther]], he had six children, four sons (the eldest, William, a [[Court of Common Pleas (England)#Justices|Judge of the Common Pleas]] under [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]) and two daughters.
==References== {{reflist}} {{DNB|wstitle=Fairfax, Guy}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fairfax, Guy}} [[Category:People of the Tudor period]] [[Category:English judges]] [[Category:15th-century English people]] [[Category:People from Yorkshire]] [[Category:Knights Bachelor]] [[Category:Fairfax family|Guy]] [[Category:15th-century births]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:1495 deaths]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Johan Petter Johansson | image = J P Johansson 1940.jpg | caption = J. P. Johansson with his favourite tool and invention, the plumber wrench. In his breast pocket, an adjustable spanner, also invented by him. | birth_date = {{birth date|1853|12|12|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Vårgårda]], [[Västra Götaland County]], [[Sweden]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1943|8|25|1853|12|12|df=y}} | death_place = | nationality = [[Sweden|Swedish]] | occupation = [[Inventor]] | known_for = Inventor of an [[adjustable spanner]] and [[plumber wrench]]. | spouse = Matilda Johansson | partner = | children = Hannes Brynge | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Johan Petter Johansson''' (December 12, 1853 – August 25, 1943), sometimes known as '''JP''', was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[inventor]] and [[industrialist]]. He invented a modern [[adjustable spanner]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bahco.com/en/about/|title=About Us {{!}} BAHCO|website=www.bahco.com|access-date=2017-02-15}}</ref> (patents in 1891 and 11 May 1892). He obtained over 100 patents in total.
He was born in [[Vårgårda]] in western Sweden, the oldest of six children in a [[croft (land)|crofter]]'s family. His was first employed as an assistant operator of a [[steam engine]] at a local [[peat]] factory. He left Vårgårda at age 19, in 1873, for [[Motala]] to work as a [[navvy]]. Following [[military]] service in 1874, he moved to [[Eskilstuna]] where he worked for the [[Bolinder-Munktell]] factory, and in 1878 he moved to [[Västerås]] where he found employment at a mechanical [[workshop]]. Following that, he worked as a [[blacksmith]] at a nearby farm.
At this time, he had made a decision to leave Sweden for the [[United States]]. This never happened; he was instead offered a more esteemed job by his former employer Munktells, and the offer changed his mind.
He eventually decided to start his own business and, in 1886, moved to [[Enköping]] where he started ''Enköpings Mekaniska Verkstad'' (the Mechanical Workshop of Enköping) which quickly became a successful venture. It was during the years in his workshop that he invented the [[adjustable spanner]] and the [[plumber wrench]]. In 1890, [[B.A. Hjorth & Company]] agreed to distribute his tools worldwide under the "[[Bahco]]" trademark. The Bahco tools became greatly successful, and the company is still in operation and has manufactured over 100 million wrenches to date.
Johansson transferred the then-large enterprise to his son, Hannes Brynge, and the B.A. Hjorth & Company in 1916. He started experimenting with electrical armature and in 1919 opened a new factory, Triplex<!-- this is the building type -->, which manufactured electrical [[pendulum]]s and various devices.
[[Image:JP Johansson gravsten.JPG|right|thumb|J. P. Johansson's grave in [[Enköping]]]] He died 89 years old after having been productive for the most of his life.
==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.jpjohanssonmuseum.com/english.asp The J.P. Johansson Museum] * Skiftnyckelns Vänner. ''[http://hem.passagen.se/skiftnyckelnsvanner/jp_johansson.html Johan Petter Johansson]''. (Retrieved February 25, 2005.) * [[Nationalencyklopedin]]. ''Johan Petter Johansson''. * [http://www.bahco.com/ Official Bahco website]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Johansson, Johan Petter}} [[Category:1853 births]] [[Category:1943 deaths]] [[Category:Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:Swedish inventors]] [[Category:Blacksmiths]]

{{EngvarB|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}}
'''John Anderson''' (1747–1820) was a Scottish businessman and entrepreneur. He was a commercial agent in New York and later a business owner in Cork. His business played a pivotal role in creating infrastructure that connected Dublin to Cork. Anderson purchased land in [[Fermoy]] that was later used as a military complex.
==Career== Anderson was born into a poor family at Portland near Dumfries, Scotland and moved to [[Glasgow]] in 1784. He later settled in Cork City, at that time the major provisioning centre on the Atlantic Coast. During the American wars he earned considerable sums as a commercial agent in New York, and made extensive land purchases in the Cork area.
His Cork enterprise was based at [[Lapp's Island]], and his business acumen was recognised as he grew rapidly in fortune and was appointed to the city's committee of merchants. He was made a Freeman of the city in 1787. Among his business interests was a malting and warehouse complex at [[Ballinacurra, County Cork|Ballinacurra]] on Cork Harbour in partnership with John Lapp, in the 1780s. In common with many Cork merchants he was in favour of union with Great Britain in 1800. Anderson's Quay in Cork is called after him. He married a Miss Semple and had two daughters and two sons, one of whom, [[Sir James Caleb Anderson, 1st Baronet|James Caleb Anderson]] (1782–1861), was a noted experimenter with steam-driven road vehicles.
His fortunes suffered a series of reversals with the fall in the value of land after the [[Napoleonic Wars]], and he lost over £30,000 in a Welsh mining venture. He had been conducting banking business and with the economic downturn his bank collapsed in 1816.
===Development of roads and coaching=== Anderson secured the equivalent of a government franchise to provide a mail service from [[Dublin]] to Cork. This involved the building of an extensive infrastructure of roads, bridges, inns and [[stage coach]] stations. By 1789 he was the dominant partner in the Dublin–Cork turnpike and mail line, which was extended to Limerick in 1793. Its paramount achievement was getting from Dublin to Cork within 24 hours, the first Royal Mail arriving in Cork 8 July 1789.
===Founding of Fermoy=== Anderson purchased lands in the [[Fermoy]] area in 1791 and responded to a British government demand for military barracks by offering to build to their order in Fermoy. The first barracks was for 1400 troop and 100 horses, later increased to a total of 3300 men. Soon a vast military complex with workshops and ancillary services together with coach workshops were functioning.
==References== * Niall Brunicarda 'John Anderson Entrepreneur' Eigse Books Fermoy 1987 * Sean Beecher Cork 365 Collins Press 2005 {{ISBN|1-903464-92-7}} * Madden ''Revelations in Ireland, A Scotchman in Munster''
==External links== * [http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mturner/cork/cork_1787.htm Cork Directory 1787] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060822072239/http://www.corkancestors.com/1790corkcity.htm Hibernian Chronicle 1790–1791] * [http://www.corkpastandpresent.ie/mapsimages/corkphotographs/michaelolearyphotos/andersonsquay/ Cork past and present photograph Anderson's Quay prior to new bridge] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080627013908/http://www.r-alston.co.uk/ch_ire.htm Fermoy House] * [http://www.electricscotland.com/history/nation/anderson.htm The Scottish Nation] * [http://www.libraryireland.com/topog/F/Fermoy-Condons-and-Clongibbons-Cork.php Lewis Topographical Dictionary]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Anderson, John (Scottish businessman)}} [[Category:Scottish businesspeople]]

{{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = [[Lieutenant Colonel]] [[The Right Honourable]] | name =The Lord Astor of Hever | image = John Jacob Astor V.jpg | caption = John Jacob Astor V, 1st Baron Astor of Hever | birth_date = {{birth date|1886|5|20|df=y}} | birth_place =[[Manhattan, New York City]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1971|7|19|1886|5|20|df=y}} | death_place = [[Cannes]], [[France]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | party = [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] | alma_mater =[[Eton College]]
[[New College, Oxford]] | spouse = [[Violet Astor|Violet Mary Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound]]
(1916–1965; her death) | children = {{plain list| *[[Gavin Astor, 2nd Baron Astor of Hever|Gavin Astor]] *Hugh Waldorf Astor *[[John Astor]] }} | parents =[[William Waldorf Astor, 1st Viscount Astor|William Waldorf Astor]]
Mary Dahlgren Paul | relatives = See [[Astor family]] }} [[Lieutenant-Colonel]] '''John Jacob Astor V, 1st Baron Astor of Hever''', [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]] (20 May 1886 – 19 July 1971) was an American-born English newspaper proprietor, politician, sportsman, military officer, and a member of the [[Astor family]]. ==Biography== Astor was born in [[Manhattan, New York City]], in 1886, the fourth child of [[William Waldorf Astor, 1st Viscount Astor]] (1848–1919), and Mary Dahlgren Paul (1858–1894). He was five years old when his family left New York to live in [[England]]. He was raised on an estate purchased by his father at [[Cliveden|Cliveden-on-Thames]] in [[Buckinghamshire]] and was educated at [[Eton College]] and at [[New College, Oxford]].{{cite book|title=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Volume 2|year=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=796|isbn=0-19-861352-0}}Article by Derek Wilson. Upon his father's death in 1919, John Jacob V inherited [[Hever Castle]] near [[Edenbridge, Kent]], where he lived the life of an English country gentleman. ===Olympic Games=== {{MedalTop}} {{Medal|Country|the {{GBR}}}} {{Medal|Sport|Men's [[Rackets at the 1908 Summer Olympics|rackets]]}} {{Medal|Gold|[[1908 Summer Olympics|1908 London]]|[[Rackets at the 1908 Summer Olympics – Men's doubles|Men's doubles]]}} {{Medal|Bronze|[[1908 Summer Olympics|1908 London]]|[[Rackets at the 1908 Summer Olympics – Men's singles|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalBottom}} John Jacob Astor V represented [[Great Britain]] in [[racquets (sport)|rackets]] at the [[1908 Summer Olympics]], winning the gold medal in the men's doubles competition together with [[Vane Pennell]], and winning bronze in the men's singles event.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} Astor had been the British Public Schools rackets champion in 1904–05, and in the same year as his Olympic competition he played singles and doubles in the British Army rackets championships.{{cite book|title=Who Was Who, 1971-1980|year=1982|publisher=A and C Black|page=30|isbn=0-7136-2176-1}} Despite a later loss of leg, he was able to play and win against younger opponents at [[Squash (sport)|squash]] on a prosthetic limb. ===Military service=== He served in the [[Life Guards (British Army)|1st Life Guards]], which he joined in 1906 after a year at Oxford, and was Aide-de-Camp to [[Charles Hardinge, 1st Baron Hardinge of Penshurst|Baron Hardinge]], [[Viceroy of India]] between 1911 and 1914. Within his regiment he was promoted Captain in 1913 and Major in 1920. In [[World War I]], he was wounded serving with his regiment at Messines in October 1914. After recovering he returned to the Western Front, rising to the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel commanding 520 Household Siege Battery of the [[Royal Garrison Artillery]] and awarded the [[Légion d'Honneur]] as a [[knight|Chevalier]]. In September 1918, near Cambrai, his right leg was shattered by a shell and later amputated. He was Honorary Colonel of the [[1st Kent Artillery Volunteers|Kent and Sussex Heavy Regiment, Royal Artillery]], between 1927 and 1946 and Honorary Colonel of the 23rd [[London Regiment]], between 1928 and 1949. In [[World War II]] he was Lieutenant-Colonel of the 5th Battalion, City of London [[Home Guard (United Kingdom)|Home Guard]], a unit drawn from newspaper employees,{{cite book|title=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Volume 2|page=797}} between 1940 and 1944. ===Marriage and children=== Astor married [[Violet Astor|Lady Violet Mary Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound]] (born 28 May 1889, died 3 January 1965) on 28 August 1916. She was the third daughter of [[Gilbert Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound, 4th Earl of Minto]] and his wife Lady Mary Caroline Grey. From her previous marriage to [[Major]] [[Lord Charles Petty-Fitzmaurice|Lord Charles George Francis Mercer Nairne Petty-Fitzmaurice]], who was [[killed in action]] at [[First Battle of Ypres|Ypres]] in 1914, Lady Violet had two children, Mary and [[George Petty-Fitzmaurice, 8th Marquess of Lansdowne|George]].[http://www.thepeerage.com/p2905.htm#i29047 The Peerage, entry for Lord Charles] Lord and Lady Astor had three sons:[http://www.thepeerage.com/p8059.htm#i80590 The Peerage, entry for 1st Lord Astor] * [[Gavin Astor, 2nd Baron Astor of Hever]] (1 June 1918 - 28 June 1984), married [[Irene Astor, Baroness Astor of Hever|Lady Irene Haig]], youngest daughter of [[Douglas Haig, 1st Earl Haig]], and Dorothy Maud Vivian, and had five children including [[John Jacob Astor VIII|John Jacob "Johnny" Astor VIII]]. * [[Lieutenant colonel (United Kingdom)|Lt Col]] [[The Honourable|Hon]] Hugh Waldorf Astor (born 20 November 1920, died 7 June 1999), married Emily Lucy Kinloch, a niece of [[Diana Vreeland]], and had five children. * Hon [[John Astor]] (born 26 September 1923, died 27 December 1987), married Diana Kathleen Drummond, a grandniece of [[Herbert Samuel Holt]], and had three children. ===Career=== He was a director of the [[Great Western Railway]] between 1929 and 1946. He held the office of Lieutenant of the [[City of London]] in 1926. He held the offices of [[Justice of the Peace]] from 1929 and Deputy Lieutenant of Kent from 1936 until 1962. He was a director of [[Hambros Bank]] between 1934 and 1960. He was Vice-Chairman of [[Phoenix Insurance]] between 1941 and 1952 and Chairman of between 1952 and 1958. He was a director of [[Barclays Bank]] between 1942 and 1952.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} In 1922, he purchased ''[[The Times]]'' newspaper following the death of its owner, [[Alfred Harmsworth, 1st Viscount Northcliffe]]. During his tenure as head of ''The Times'', Lord Astor had the newspaper sponsor [[Edmund Hillary]]'s expedition that made the first successful climb to the summit of [[Mount Everest]]. Astor remained chairman of the paper until 1959 when his son Gavin took over. In 1966, ''The Times'' was sold to [[Canadians|Canadian]] newspaper tycoon, [[Roy Herbert Thomson, 1st Baron Thomson of Fleet|Roy Thomson]]. Astor served as the first chairman of the [[Press Council (UK)|General Council of the Press]], which was established in 1953. He resigned from the position in April 1955 due to ill-health.{{Cite book|title=The Press and the People|last=|first=|publisher=General Council of the Press|year=1955|isbn=|location=|pages=2}} In addition to his newspaper business, John Jacob V served in politics, as [[Alderman]] of the [[London County Council]] between 1922 and 1925, and in the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]] for 23 years as [[Conservative Party (UK)|Unionist]] [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Dover (UK Parliament constituency)|Dover]] from 1922 to 1945. On 21 January 1956 he was created '''Baron Astor of Hever''', ''of Hever Castle, in the County of Kent''.{{London Gazette |issue=40692 |date=24 January 1956 |page=499}} In 1962, he moved from England to France. ===Death=== He died on 19 July 1971 in [[Cannes]], [[France]].{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Lord Astor of Hever Is Dead, Published The Times of London. American-Born Press Lord Headed Newspaper for 37 Years. Served in House of Commons 1922-1945 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C0CE5D6113FEF34BC4851DFB166838A669EDE |quote=Lord Astor of Hever, former publisher of The Times of London, died today ... |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=20 July 1971 |accessdate=2014-07-27 }} ==Legacy== Selected artworks from the family's vast collection were bequeathed to the [[National Gallery]] including the prized "''Thames below Westminster''" by [[Claude Monet]]. John Jacob V and Violet are buried together on the grounds of Hever Castle, which, since 1983, has been owned by Broadland Properties Limited and is a major tourist attraction. Eldest son Gavin succeeded him as Baron.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} ==Further reading== *[http://www.thepeerage.com/p8059.htm#i80590] *{{Rayment|date=February 2012}} *{{Rayment-hc|date=March 2012}} *{{Find a Grave|12260}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070929171136/http://www.databaseolympics.com/players/playerpage.htm?ilkid=ASTORJOH01 profile] *[http://www.biography.com/people/john-jacob-astor-v-9191184] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Hansard-contribs | lieut-colonel-hon-john-jacob-astor | John Jacob Astor }} general election, 1945|1945]] | before = [[Thomas Andrew Polson]] | after = [[John Thomas (UK politician)|John Thomas]] }} {{s-reg|uk}} {{s-new | creation}} {{s-ttl | title = [[Baron Astor of Hever]] '''Johnny Reklai''' (July 1, 1948 – March 11, 2007) was a [[Palau]]an businessman and [[politician]]. At the time of his death he was serving as the president of the [[Senate of Palau]]. He was succeeded in that office by [[Surangel S. Whipps]], and his seat was filled by [[Hokkons Baules]].
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071110050903/http://www.palauoek.net/senate/ReklaiMemorial.asp Memorial on senate website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Reklai, Johnny}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Presidents of the Senate of Palau]] [[Category:People from Ngarchelong]] [[Category:Palauan businesspeople]]
{{Palau-politician-stub}}

'''Datuk Kasi K.L. Palaniappan''' is a prominent [[Malaysia]]n businessman.
Born in 1958, he is a former architect and university professor. He founded MK Land with Mustapha Kamal Abu Bakar. He took over as managing director and acting chief executive in April 2006; share prices of the company subsequently doubled.
[[Forbes]] Asia ranked him as 40th on their List of 40 Richest Malaysians, with a personal wealth of US$127 million.
==References== * [https://www.forbes.com/lists/2007/84/biz_07malaysia_Kasi-K-L-Palaniappan_4Y3F.html Forbes.com - Kasi K.L. Palaniappan]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Palaniappan, K.L.}} [[Category:Malaysian businesspeople]] [[Category:Malaysian people of Indian descent]] [[Category:Tamil businesspeople]] [[Category:Businesspeople of Indian descent]] [[Category:Malaysian people of Tamil descent]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Malaysian architects]]
