{{Infobox person | name = Keith Weed | image = Keith Weed.jpg | caption = | birth_place = [[United Kingdom]] | nationality = [[England|English]] | ethnicity = | education = | alma_mater = [[University of Liverpool|Liverpool University]] | occupation = [[Chief marketing officer|CMCO]] of [[Unilever]] | years_active = | title = Chief Marketing and Communications Officer | term = 2010-present }}
'''Keith Weed''', born in 1961, is [[Unilever]]'s [[Chief marketing officer|CMCO]], responsible for the marketing and communications functions, a role which also includes leadership of Unilever's sustainability agenda and the Unilever corporate brand. He has held this role since 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/keith-weed-chief-marketing-communications-officer-unilever/1373048|title=Keith Weed, Chief marketing and communications officer, Unilever|publisher=}}</ref> Before this he was Unilever's Head of Global Home Care & Hygiene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bitc.org.uk/about-us/who-we-are/keith-weed|title=Keith Weed|date=24 June 2014|publisher=}}</ref>
== Education == Weed obtained a Bachelor of Engineering with First Class Honours from [[University of Liverpool|Liverpool University]] in 1983.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creativebrief.com/blog/2011/09/20/market-leader-interview-–-keith-weed-chief-marketing-and-communication-officer-unilever/|title=Market Leader Interview – Keith Weed, Chief Marketing and Communication Officer, Unilever|publisher=}}</ref> In 2012 he was awarded an Honorary Doctorate from [[Southampton Solent University]] recognising his contributions to business.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.solent.ac.uk/graduation/honorary-graduates|title=Honorary graduates|publisher=}}</ref>
== Career == Weed worked as an engineer after graduating university before joining Unilever in 1983 as a marketer. Throughout his career at Unilever, he has been chairman of Lever Fabergé and chairman of Unilever Export.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/unilever-creates-lever-faberge-uk-consolidation/70321|title=Unilever creates Lever Faberge in UK consolidation|publisher=}}</ref> He has worked for Unilever in the UK, France, the United States, both in global and regional roles across general management and marketing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.weforum.org/people/keith-weed/|title=Keith Weed - World Economic Forum|publisher=}}</ref> More recently he was global head of Home Care & Hygiene, covering Fabric Cleaning, Fabric Conditioning, Household Cleaning Products, Oral Care and Portable Water.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intelligenthq.com/profiles/cmo-profile-keith-weed-unilever/|title=CMO Profile: Keith Weed Managing Marketing Strategy for Unilever|date=24 March 2012|publisher=}}</ref> As Unilever's Chief Marketing and Communications Officer, Weed is on Unilever's executive board with the Marketing, Communications and Sustainable Business teams reporting to him.
Since becoming CMCO, Weed has pioneered new ways of integrating sustainability in business and led the creation of the Unilever Sustainable Living Plan <ref>{{cite web|url=https://hbr.org/2014/07/reinventing-the-chief-marketing-officer-an-interview-with-unilever-cmo-keith-weed|title=Harvard Business Review - Reinventing the Chief Marketing Officer|publisher=}}</ref>. Weed dissolved Unilever's Corporate Social Responsibility department <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/new-type-csr-why-i-disbanded-unilevers-department-nutshell-keith-weed|title=Why I Disbanded Unilever's CSR Department=}}</ref> and has integrated sustainable growth throughout Unilever’s business. The Unilever Sustainable Living Plan <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.unilever.com/sustainable-living/our-strategy/|title=USLP =}}</ref> seeks to grow the business while reducing its environmental footprint and increasing its social impact. In 2014, Weed gave a [[TED Talk]] about the global issue of climate change and argues that sustainability and economic growth can go hand-in-hand.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ted.com/watch/ted-institute/ted-unilever/keith-weed-the-power-of-transformative-collaboration|title=Keith Weed: Sustainability - the logic and power of transformative collaboration}}</ref>.
Weed has also directed significant advances in digital <ref>https://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/unilevers-keith-weed-put-price-trust-tech-giants/1456432</ref> and influencer <ref>http://www.thedrum.com/news/2018/06/25/influencer-marketing-fraud-how-big-problem-it</ref> marketing and technologies within Unilever, championing the 3Vs of Viewability, Verification and Value across the industry. He is committed to tackling stereotypes - gender and beyond - in advertising through Unilever's #Unstereotype <ref>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/jun/22/unilever-sexist-stereotypes-ads-sunsilk-dove-lynx</ref> initiative and is the architect behind the #Unstereotype Alliance <ref>http://www.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2018/6/press-release-unstereotype-alliance-first-anniversary</ref>, co-created with UN Women, bringing together 24 companies to remove the portrayal of unhelpful stereotypes from their advertising by 2020.
In 2016 Weed was [[LinkedIn]]'s second most influential writer on the platform in the UK.<ref>https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/linkedin-top-voices-2016-15-must-know-writers-uk-katie-carroll</ref>
In 2017, he was voted as the Marketers Marketer of the Year by [http://www.campaignlive.co.uk Campaign] readers. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://marketors.org/liveryman-keith-weed-honoured-marketers-marketer-campaigns-power-100/|title=Liveryman Keith Weed honoured as Marketers’ Marketer in Campaign’s Power 100|date=9 March 2007|website=www.Marketors.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|last1=Garland Worthington|first1=Sue|accessdate=13 July 2017}}</ref> He was also voted Global Marketer of the Year 2017 by the [https://www.wfanet.org World Federation of Advertisers] <ref>https://www.wfanet.org/globalmarketeroftheyear/</ref>.
Weed was named the World's Most Influential CMO in 2018 and 2017 by [[Forbes]]. <ref>https://www.forbes.com/sites/jenniferrooney/2017/06/22/the-worlds-most-influential-cmos-2017/#7f0b93307f91|title=The World's Most Influential CMOs 2017|last=Rooney|first=Jennifer|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-07-13}}</ref> <ref>https://www.forbes.com/sites/jenniferrooney/2018/06/21/the-worlds-most-influential-cmos-2018/#15252fd51e66</ref>.
In 2018 Weed also received [http://www.thedrum.com The Drum]'s Lifetime Achievement Award <ref>http://www.thedrum.com/news/2018/05/14/unilevers-chief-marketing-comms-officer-keith-weed-receive-the-drums-lifetime</ref> and featured in the Top 50 Financial Times HERoes list as a Champion of Women in Business <ref>https://www.ft.com/content/4bd11478-baac-11e8-8dfd-2f1cbc7ee27c</ref>.
Outside Unilever, Weed is the President of the Advertising Association <ref>https://www.adassoc.org.uk/2018/07/advertising-association-names-unilever-chief-marketing-and-communications-officer-keith-weed-as-president/</ref>, a fellow of The Marketing Society, of which he was president from 2003 to 2006, and is a fellow of the [[Institution of Mechanical Engineers|Institute of Mechanical Engineers]].  He was a non-executive director of [[Sun Products|Sun Products Corporation]] from 2008 to 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/people/17216787-keith-weed|title=Keith Weed, Unilever NV: Profile & Biography|publisher=}}</ref> He is currently Chairman of Business in the Community International, a board of trustees director for [[Business in the Community]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bitc.org.uk/about-us/who-we-are/our-board-and-governance |title=BITC Our Board and Governance|publisher=}}</ref>, a Board Director of the [https://www.effie.org/worldwide/about Effies].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.effie.org/worldwide/directors|title=Effie|website=www.effie.org|access-date=2017-07-13}}</ref> and a trustee of Grange Park Opera <ref>https://grangeparkopera.co.uk</ref>.
==References== {{reflist}}

'''Lek Viriyaphant''' ({{lang-th|เล็ก วิริยะพันธุ์}}, sometimes referred to as Khun Lek; 1914 – November 17, 2000) was an eccentric [[Thai people|Thai]] millionaire and patron of culture responsible for the construction of [[Ancient Siam]], [[Erawan Museum]] and [[Sanctuary of Truth]].
==See also== *[[Luang Pu Bunleua Sulilat]] / [[Sala Keoku]] / [[Buddha Park]] *[[Chalermchai Kositpipat]] / [[Wat Rong Khun]] *[[Wat Pa Maha Chedi Kaew]] *[[Visionary environments]]

revision.comment: /* Sodas */
revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=February 2013}} [[PepsiCo]] has produced a number of variations on its primary [[cola]], [[Pepsi]], over the years, including the following:
==Sodas== {{Repetition|date=August 2008}} *'''[[Pepsi]]''': [[PepsiCo]]'s signature cola flavor and its namesake cola. *'''[[Caffeine-Free Pepsi|Pepsi Free]]''': Introduced in 1982 by PepsiCo as the first major-brand caffeine-free cola and is today sold as [[Caffeine-Free Pepsi]] and [[Caffeine-Free Pepsi|Caffeine-Free Diet Pepsi]]. *'''[[Pepsi Wild Cherry]]''': Introduced in 1988, it is cherry flavored cola. Known as Wild Cherry Pepsi until 2005. It was named Wild Cherry to not be confused with Coke's Cherry variation. Available nationally in the [[United States]], [[Canada]] and [[Russia]]. *'''[[Crystal Pepsi]]''': the Clear version of cola; introduced in 1992 and sold until 1993, it returned in 2015 as part of a limited sweepstakes promotion, and has been re-released several times since. **'''Crystal from Pepsi''': Discontinued citrus/cola hybrid; reformulation of Crystal Pepsi<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/news/pepsi-sees-citrus-appeal-crystal/90890/|title=PEPSI SEES CITRUS APPEAL IN ITS CRYSTAL|publisher=}}</ref> **'''Pepsi Clear''': Clear Pepsi released in Mexico as a limited edition during Christmas 2005, the Mexican equivalent of Crystal Pepsi. *'''Pepsi AM''': Contains more [[caffeine]] than a regular Pepsi and marketed as a morning drink. Introduced in 1989 and discontinued in 1990. *'''Pepsi Fresh''': Made only for summer 2007.{{Specify|date=March 2010}} *'''Pepsi X''' - 2012 release (Dragon Fruit Cola) Marketed from X Factor television show. *'''Pepsi Candy''': Sold in [[Canada]] in 1999 in the Spring as a sweeter version with a fruity taste. *'''[[Pepsi Raw]]''': "a new cola made with only natural ingredients", released in select markets in 2009 and discontinued along with its variant Pepsi Raw in 2011. *'''[[Pepsi Blue]]''': A blue colored fruity soda (described as a "Berry Cola Fusion"). Given a huge marketing push, often considered a major flop on the order of [[New Coke]]. No longer produced. In Iceland, Pepsi Blue was sold for a brief period of time during the winter of 2003/2004, and in India during the [[2003 Cricket World Cup]]. It was sold for a longer period in [[Austria]], and is still available in some parts of [[Mexico]]. It is also still available in [[Indonesia]]. It was also sold in the Philippines for a limited time only, usually, it appears during Christmas season. Likewise, it was sold for a limited time in Australia, [[Bulgaria]], [[Poland]], [[Finland]], and [[Romania]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} *'''Pepsi Gold''': Limited edition gold colored variant as part of a [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] and [[ICC Cricket World Cup 2007]] promotion. It had a hint of ginger, but nowhere near the spice level of Pepsi Red, and was sold in Southeast Asia, Central Europe, Finland, Russia, [[Turkey]], and The Middle East. Re-released as Pepsi Cheer for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]]. *'''Pepsi Holiday Spice''': a limited edition variety which the company began selling November 1, 2004 in the U.S. and Canada for an eight-week period, and again in the 2006 Christmas season. It is flavored with a seasonal finish of [[cinnamon]], somewhat similar to the Swedish [[Julmust]]. **'''Christmas Pepsi:''' Almost identical to Pepsi Holiday Spice, with nutmeg and cocoa added to the ingredients list, and was marketed over the 2007 and 2008 Christmas seasons. *'''Pepsi Kona''', a coffee-flavored cola which was test-marketed on the East Coast of the USA. *'''Lemon Pepsi''': Limited Edition to promote NFL kickoff 2008, same taste as Pepsi Twist *'''Pepsi Lime''': with lime flavor added, introduced onto the market in 2005 to rival Coca-Cola Lime. Currently sold in Canada, Russia, and Uganda alongside Diet Pepsi Lime. *'''Pepsi Mojito''': Lemon-flavored Pepsi, with a twist of mint. Alcohol-Free. Limited edition, summer 2009. *'''Pepsi Raging Razzberry''': Available in test markets in 1991 and it has been said that it didn't really taste like raspberry, but was considered a raspberry twist, introduced along with '''Pepsi Tropical Chill''' and '''Pepsi Strawberry Burst'''. *'''Pepsi Strawberry Burst''': Available in test markets in 1991 along with '''Pepsi Tropical Chill''' and '''Pepsi Raging Razzberry'''. *'''Pepsi Summer Mix''': Pepsi with tropical fruit flavors. Released in early Spring of 2007, and was discontinued Fall to Winter of 2007. Was available in limited areas only; was a big hit for the northeastern United States. *'''[[Pepsi-Cola Made with Real Sugar]]''': A version of Pepsi-Cola sweetened with [[sugar]] instead of [[high-fructose corn syrup]] and lacking citric acid, known as '''Pepsi Throwback''' until 2014. *'''Pepsi Tropical Chill''': Available in test markets in 1991 along with '''Pepsi Strawberry Burst''' and '''Pepsi Raging Razzberry'''. *'''Pepsi Freeze''': Pepsi, Diet Pepsi, or Wild Cherry Pepsi-flavored slushee available at most convenience stores and some movie theatres. *'''[[Pepsi Twist]]''': A lemon-flavored variety, still sold in [[Venezuela]], [[Brazil]], [[Cambodia]], [[Croatia]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Germany]], [[Hungary]], [[Indonesia]], [[Italy]], [[Malaysia]], [[Netherlands]], [[Turkey]], [[Poland]], [[Serbia]], [[Portugal]], [[Spain]], [[Romania]], [[Slovakia]], [[Finland]], and [[Greece]]. Pepsi Twist was released in [[Sweden]] in 2003 but has since been discontinued. *'''Pepsi Vanilla''': Released in Canada and the US in 2003 as Pepsi's answer to [[Vanilla Coke]]. Contains [[vanilla]] extract as well as both natural and artificial flavors. Re-launched as Cherry Vanilla Pepsi in 2010 with the addition of natural cherry flavor. Re-launched with real sugar in June 2014.<ref>{{cite journal |url= http://www.vendingtimes.com/ME2/dirmod.asp?sid=EB79A487112B48A296B38C81345C8C7F&nm=Vending+Features&type=Publishing&mod=Publications%3A%3AArticle&mid=8F3A7027421841978F18BE895F87F791&tier=4&id=DA6E913599044227BE19046C31658365 |title= Real Sugar Pepsi Hits Market |first= Emily |last= Jed |volume= 54 |number= 7|date= July 2014 |work= Vending Times |publisher= posted online June 20, 2014 |accessdate= 10 January 2016}}</ref> *'''Pepsi X Energy Cola''': Contains more caffeine than regular Pepsi, and also contains [[guaranine]]. Pepsi is the first major cola brand to have an [[energy drink]] line extension. The cola-based product has a unique flavor and a reddish tint. It was available in several countries like Russia, Sweden, Denmark, The Netherlands, Vietnam, Brazil etc. *'''Pepsi 100''': Only available for a limited time to celebrate 100 years of the drink in 1998 and came back in 2003 to celebrate the name. *'''Pepsi Cherry Vanilla''': A Cherry-Vanilla-flavored Pepsi, released in May 2010 for the summer. Re-introduced for Valentine's Day 2016. *'''1893 Original Cola''': A bold combination of kola nuts, real sugar, and sparkling water, marketed under the Pepsi brand. Released in the United States March 2016.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailymeal.com/news/drink/pepsi-s-mysterious-new-craft-soda-here-pepsi-1893-original-and-ginger-cola/032516|title=Pepsi’s Mysterious New Craft Soda Is Here: Pepsi 1893 Original and Ginger Cola|access-date=2016-09-22}}</ref> *'''1893 Ginger Cola''': A caffeinated ginger-ale beverage, marketed under the Pepsi brand. Released in Canada (as "Pepsi Ginger Cola") and the United States in March 2016.<ref name=":0" /> *'''1893 Black Currant Cola''': A currant and berry flavored cola beverage soft-launched in February 2017, with a full rollout scheduled for spring.<ref>[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/1893-from-the-makers-of-pepsi-cola-expands-portfolio-with-two-bold-new-flavors-citrus-cola-and-black-currant-cola-300416152.html 1893 From The Makers of Pepsi-Cola Expands Portfolio with Two Bold New Flavors, Citrus Cola and Black Currant Cola] (press release, March 1, 2017</ref> *'''1893 Citrus Cola''': A grapefruit-flavored cola released concurrently with Black Currant in 2017. *'''2017 Pepsi Fire''': A cinnamon infused Pepsi flavor that was sold for a limited time in summer 2017. *'''2017 Salted Caramel Pepsi''': A caramel-flavored Pepsi that was released for a limited time in Winter 2017.
===Europe=== *'''Pepsi Blue''': sold in [[Bulgaria]] (where Pepsi (Blue), Pepsi Light (see ''Diet Pepsi Light'' below), Pepsi Twist and Pepsi MAX are also found sometimes),<ref>{{cite web |url= http://pepsi.bg |website= Pepsi.bg |title= Pepsi Bulgaria |location=Bulgaria ||accessdate= 27 September 2015}}</ref> [[Denmark]], [[Finland]], [[Italy]], [[Romania]], [[Hungary]], and [[Turkey]]. *'''Pepsi Ice Cream''': was sold in [[Russia]], it reportedly tasted like [[cream soda]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://weburbanist.com/2010/05/02/global-cola-10-pepsi-cola-flavors-you-cant-get-here/ |website= WebUrbanist.com |title= Global Cola: 10 Pepsi-Cola Flavors You Can’t Get Here |date= May 2, 2010 |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> *'''[[Pepsi Raw]]''': cola made with all-natural ingredients and no artificial colours. No longer sold.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.foodmanufacture.co.uk/NPD/Pepsi-RAW-Where-did-it-all-go-wrong |title= Pepsi RAW: Where did it all go wrong? |website= FoodManufacture.co.uk |first1= Elaine |last1= Watson |first2= Ben |last2= Bouckley |date= September 7, 2010 |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Boom''': a non-caffeine, sugar, and artificial sweetener-free Pepsi only sold in Germany, [[Italy]], and [[Spain]]. *'''Pepsi Cream''': a.k.a. Pepsi Vanilla and Ice Cream sold in [[France]], [[Switzerland]], and Germany in 2005. *'''Pepsi Cappuccino''': (also known as '''Café Chino'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2006/01/20/stories/2006012002131500.htm |title=Pepsi Café Chino launched |work=The Hindu Business Line |date=2006-01-20 |accessdate=2010-06-01}}</ref> and '''Max Cino'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://snackspot.org.uk/thread.php?story=0601091324daa |title=Pepsi Max Cino |publisher=Snackspot.org.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-06-01}}</ref>) Pepsi with a taste of coffee - was sold in Russia, Romania, and sold in other various parts of Europe. *'''Pepsi La Liga''': Kola-flavored drink from Spain to promote La Liga in 2000. *'''Pepsi Samba''': a "Tropical Flavoured Cola" containing the flavors [[mango]] and [[tamarind]], distributed in [[Australia]] and could be found in some shops in [[Spain]]. It was released in [[Australia]] in the third quarter of 2005 and was expected to be in production for a limited time only. *'''Pepsi Peach''': was sold in [[Portugal]] in 1996 and had a sweet [[peach]] taste. With a hint of [[cream soda]] and was Pepsi answer to Germany's [[Mezzo Mix]]. But it vanished months later off [[Portugal|Portuguese]] stores after poor sales. Pepsi has had similar brands like it in other countries, using [[mango]] mixed with Pepsi. *'''Pepsi Summer Chill''': "Chilled Apple Cola", sold in Poland during summer 2007; in the Czech Republic and Slovakia the same product was sold as Pepsi Ice. *'''Pepsi Tropical''': sold in the UK and France in late 1994; it had a pineapple and sweet orange taste. *'''Pepsi Punch''': sold along with Pepsi Tropical in late 1994 in both the UK and France; it had a sweet coconut and fruit punch taste, and it was packaged in a purple and blue can. *'''Pepsi Raspberry'''* : Sold for Limited time in [[France|French]] stores. *'''Pepsi Twist Mojito''': a Pepsi with a mix of lemon and mojito taste. *'''Pepsi Ginga''': Pepsi Ginga is a summer edition of Pepsi sold in Romania & Denmark in 2014. Ginga is inspired by the Brazilian culture and has a citrus flavour.
===Japan=== *'''Pepsi Azuki''': An [[azuki bean]]-flavored limited edition Pepsi released on October 20, 2009.<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.suntory.co.jp/news/2009/10568.html |title= 「ペプシあずき」季節限定発売|trans-title= 'Pepsi Azuki' seasonal sale |quote= Suntory Food Co., Ltd., and a seasonal sale in the country from the "Pepsi Azuki" October 20 as a lineup of PEPSI (Tuesday). |language= Japanese |website= Suntory.co.jp |date= September 29, 2009 |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Baobab''': A [[baobab tree]] fruit-flavored, limited edition Pepsi released on May 25, 2010.<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.suntory.co.jp/news/2010/10746.html |title= ペプシバオバブ」季節限定発売 |trans-title= 'Pepsi Baobab' seasonal sale |quote= Suntory Food Co., Ltd., and a seasonal sale in the country from the "Pepsi Baobab" May 25 as a lineup of PEPSI (Tuesday). |language= Japanese |website= Suntory.co.jp |date= April 27, 2010 |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Black''': A soda similar to Pepsi Dry, with 50% less sugar than regular Pepsi, and blacker in color, released in Summer 2012, by Suntory. *'''Pepsi Blue Hawaii''': A summer 2008 limited edition, pineapple and lemon-flavored Pepsi, blue in color.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.theimpulsivebuy.com/wordpress/2008/06/25/pepsi-blue-hawaii/ |title= REVIEW: Pepsi Blue Hawaii |date= June 25, 2008 |author= Marvo |website=TheImpulsiveBuy.com |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Caribbean Gold''': A limited edition, golden-colored, [[white sapote]] fruit-flavored Pepsi released on July 26, 2011.<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://products.suntory.co.jp/d/4901777222960/index.html |title= Suntory to release Caribbean Gold on July 26, 2011 |language= Japanese |website= Suntory.co.jp |date= |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *'''Pepsi Carnival''': A tropical fruit-flavored Pepsi available in Japan for a limited time that debuted in summer 2006. The same concept was later released as '''Pepsi Summer Mix''' in 2007 in the US, although the formula was most likely different. *'''Pepsi Christmas Cola''': A limited edition, Christmas themed Pepsi released November 21, 2017. While not cake batter flavored, the creamy white cola and strawberry combination are reminiscent of the whipped cream and strawberries of a traditional Japanese Christmas cake.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://kotaku.com/cake-flavored-pepsi-coming-to-japan-1820209917 |title= Cake-Flavored Pepsi Coming To Japan |website= Kotaku.com |date= November 7, 2017 |accessdate= November 14, 2017}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Dry''': Limited edition non-sweet (but not completely sugar-free) Bitter Pepsi variant released by Suntory on May 24, 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://inventorspot.com/articles/how_sweet_it_isnt_new_pepsi_dry_bitter_better |title=How Sweet it Isn't: With New 'Pepsi Dry', Bitter is Better |first= Steve |last= Levenstein |website=InventorySpot.com |date= April 28, 2011 |publisher= quoting WalkerPlus.com, April 27, 2011}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Extra''' *'''Pepsi Ghost''': Released on October 6, 2015. The bottles featured Halloween themed labels, while the flavor was an unidentified mystery flavor.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://en.rocketnews24.com/2015/10/06/pepsi-ghost-brings-a-mysterious-new-flavor-for-halloween-in-japan/ |website= RocketNews24.com |title= 'Pepsi Ghost' Brings a Mysterious New Flavor for Halloween in Japan |author= Master Blaster |date= October 6, 2015 |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Halloween Cola''': Released in October 2017, this "mystery" flavor was pink, with a sweet cherry and bubblegum flavor. It also somewhat resembled past Sakura flavored Pepsi.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.japantimes.co.jp/life/2017/09/30/food/pepsi-halloween-cola-pink-drink-may-sweet/ |website= Japantimes.co.jp |title= 'Pepsi Halloween Cola: Pink drink may be too sweet for some |author= Patrick St. Michel |date= September 30, 2017 |accessdate= November 11, 2017}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Ice Cucumber''': Limited edition green, cucumber-flavored Pepsi sold in summer 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.foodieprints.com/item/169 |title= Introducing Pepsi Ice Cucumber |website=FoodiePrints.com}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Nex Zero''' *'''Pepsi Mont Blanc''': a Limited edition Pepsi based on the French chestnut dessert. Sold for a limited time from October 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://inventorspot.com/articles/pepsi_mont_blanc_bottles_flavors_chestnuts_and_snow |title= Pepsi Mont Blanc Bottles The Flavor Of Chestnuts |first= Steve |last= Levenstein |website=InventorySpot.com |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Pink''': Limited edition pink, strawberry milk-flavored Pepsi released on November 8, 2011 for a limited time.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://products.suntory.co.jp/d/4901777225527/index.html |title= Suntory to release Pepsi Pink on November 8, 2011 |website= suntory.co.jp |language= Japanese}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> It was released again in 2014.<ref>{{cite news |title= Pink strawberry milk Pepsi set to return to stores in Japan this winter |first= Casey |last= Baseel |date= October 29, 2014 |url= http://en.rocketnews24.com/2014/10/29/pink-strawberry-milk-pepsi-set-to-return-to-stores-in-japan-this-winter/ |website= RocketNews24.com |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Red''': Released in 2006, it had a ginger flavor that was somewhat spicy. *'''Pepsi Sakura''': A floral cherry blossom flavored Pepsi, released in Japan in March 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rocketnews24.com/2016/02/08/worlds-first-ever-sakura-pepsi-coming-to-japan-this-march/|title=World's first-ever Sakura Pepsi coming to Japan this March|date=8 February 2016|publisher=}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Salty Watermelon''': A watermelon flavored Pepsi, sold in Japan in June 2012 for a limited time only. *'''Pepsi Shiso''': Limited edition green [[shiso]]-flavored soda sold during summer 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.theimpulsivebuy.com/wordpress/2009/07/07/review-pepsi-shiso/ |website= TheImpulsiveBuy.com |title= REVIEW: Pepsi Shiso |date= July 7, 2009 |author= Marvo |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> *'''[[Pepsi Special]]''': Has ingredient to limit absorption of fat. *'''Pepsi Special Lemon Mint:''' A limited edition Pepsi released in the summer of 2015. It was a zero calorie soda touted to meet the Food for Specified Health Uses (FOSHU) standards.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://en.rocketnews24.com/2015/07/29/is-the-world-ready-for-japans-newest-lemon-and-mint-pepsi-flavor/ |title= Is the world ready for Lemon & Mint Pepsi? |date= July 29, 2015 |first= Mike |last= Oakland |website= RocketNews24.com |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Strong Shot:''' A limited edition Pepsi released in 2010 with a high concentration of caffeine and extra carbonation. Followed up on in 2015 with Pepsi Strong and Pepsi Strong Zero. These were sold in larger sizes and with an even higher concentration of caffeine and carbonation.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://en.rocketnews24.com/2015/05/21/pepsi-strong-newest-drink-in-the-pepsi-line-up-is-ready-to-kick-your-butt/ |title= Pepsi Strong: Newest drink in the Pepsi line-up is ready to kick your butt |date= May 21, 2015 |first= Audrey |last= Akcasu |website= RocketNews24.com |accessdate= May 18, 2017}}</ref> This was further followed up on in May 2016 with Pepsi Strong 5.0 GV, a soda so carbonated that a new bottle had to be designed to contain it.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://en.rocketnews24.com/2016/05/19/japan-gets-worlds-strongest-carbonated-pepsi-packaged-in-a-new-reinforced-bottle/ |title= Japan gets world’s strongest carbonated Pepsi, packaged in a new reinforced bottle |date= May 19, 2016 |first= Oona |last= McGee |website= RocketNews24.com |accessdate= May 18, 2017}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Tropical''': Short-lived drink that was available in the US, UK and Japan in late 1994.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.123helpme.com/failed-product-report-crystal-pepsi-view.asp?id=166232 |website= 123HelpMe.com |title= Failed Product Report: Crystal Pepsi |date= |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> *'''Pepsi White''': Limited edition Pepsi with yogurt flavor, sold in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japanmarketingnews.com/2008/10/suntory-intros.html|title=Breville Juicer BJE510XL: The Best Juicer For Your Healthy Living - Bestbuyhq - Top rated Products and Reviews|date=9 April 2017|publisher=}}</ref> It was released again for a limited time in winter 2012 with a mandarin orange flavor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rocketnews24.com/2012/10/31/japans-new-pepsi-white-is-flavored-orange/|title=Japan's New Pepsi White is Flavored Orange|date=31 October 2012|publisher=}}</ref> Another variant called White Cola Pepsi was released in 2015, with a light citrus flavor similar to the 2012 version.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/new-products/view/citrus-packing-pepsi-white|title=Citrus-packing Pepsi White|publisher=}}</ref>
===Latin America=== *'''Pepsi Limón''': Pepsi with lime flavor released in Mexico in 2002, later returns as [[Pepsi Twist]] in 2004, no longer produced. **'''Pepsi Twistão''' Sold during summertime in Brazil, it is a Pepsi with a lemon flavor stronger than regular Pepsi Twist. "Twistão", in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], is the [[augmentative]] of "Twist". *'''Pepsi Capuchino''' a blend of cola with mocha-latte coffee flavor. Released for a limited time in Guatemala<ref>{{cite web|last1=Medina|first1=Rafaello|title=Pepsi o Capuchino - El nuevo producto estará en el mercado guatemalteco a partir de enero de 2006.|trans-title=Pepsi or Cappuccino - The new product will be in the Guatemalan market from January 2006|language=Spanish|url=http://www.elperiodico.com.gt/es/20051227/actualidad/23196/|website=ElPeriodico.com|date=|accessdate=2014-07-31|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811172625/http://www.elperiodico.com.gt/es/20051227/actualidad/23196/|archivedate=2014-08-11|df=}}</ref> and El Salvador<ref>{{cite web|last1=Medina|first1=Rafaello|title=Guerra de precios en las sodas|trans-title= Price War in Soda |language= Spanish |url=http://www.elsalvador.com/noticias/2006/01/23/negocios/neg9.asp|website=ElSalvador.com |date= January 23, 2006 |accessdate=2014-07-31}}</ref> in 2006 in {{convert|600|ml|usfloz|abbr=on}} bottles. Later introduced in Honduras in 2012. *'''Pepsi Retro''' (rendered in written advertisement as '''PEPSI retro'''): Released in Mexico in February 2008. Pepsi made with natural ingredients, sugar cane, and cola nut extract. *'''Pecsi''': Pepsi spelled differently as "Pecsi," made in Argentina in 2009<ref>{{cite web|last=Vescovi |first=Valentina |url= http://adage.com/article/global-news/pepsi-pecsi-argentina/137946/ |title=Pepsi Becomes 'Pecsi' in Argentina |publisher=''Advertising Age'' |website=Adage.com |date=2009-07-15 |accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref> and Mexico in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.tuvez.com/videos/pepsi-now-selling-as-pecsi-in-mexico/ |title=Pepsi Now Selling As 'Pecsi' In Mexico |website=Tuvez.com |date= March 2011 |accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Kaffe''' one of a number of coffee-flavored Pepsi variants introduced outside the US in the 2000s<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.just-drinks.com/analysis/coca-cola-blak-to-the-drawing-board_id91450.aspx|first=Annette|last=Farr|title=ANALYSIS: (Coca-Cola) Blak to the drawing-board|work=Just Drinks|date=2007-09-06}}</ref>
===Other markets=== *'''Pepsi Blue Chilled Cola''', simply '''Pepsi Blue''', which was promoted by [[Britney Spears]] was released in Vietnam. Another version of Pepsi, '''Pepsi Ice''' Mint flavored Pepsi sold for a limited time along with Pepsi Fire in south east Asia including Malaysia *'''Pepsi Cheer''', a sweet syrup tasting style of Pepsi sold in [[Thailand]] in 2010. *'''Pepsi Fire''': a limited edition, cinnamon-flavored variety that is sold in [[Guam]], [[Saipan]], [[Thailand]], [[Mexico]], [[Malaysia]], [[Singapore]], the [[Philippines]], and [[Vietnam]]. It is also a Pepsi Ice twin version. *'''Pepsi Green''': a bright-green variety introduced in Thailand on January 15, 2009.<ref>{{cite news |work=[[Bangkok Post]] |url= http://www.bangkokpost.com/business/economics/9834/pepsi-eyes-growth-despite-slow-market |title= Pepsi Eyes Growth Despite Slow Market |first= Kitja |last= Apichonrojarek |date= January 16, 2009 |accessdate= January 27, 2009}}</ref> *'''Pepsi Ice''': Pepsi with an icy mint flavor. Sold in Guam, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, and the [[Philippines]]. In summer 2007 Pepsi used the name Pepsi Ice in the Czech Republic and Slovakia for a limited edition cola with apple flavor. *'''Pepsi Aha''': Lemon-flavored Pepsi sold in India *'''Pepsi Pinas''': Pepsi Blue renamed sold in Philippines *'''Pepsi Pogi''': Sold only in Philippines *'''Pepsi Latte''': Sold in Thailand *'''Pepsi Tarik''': Coffee-flavored, sold in Malaysia and Singapore
==Diet variants== *'''[[Diet Pepsi]]''': Low-calorie version of Pepsi. *'''Diet Crystal Pepsi''': Low-calorie version of Crystal Pepsi. *'''Diet Pepsi AM''': Sugar-free version of Pepsi AM, and introduced in 1987. No longer produced. *'''Pepsi Edge''': contains half the [[carbohydrate]]s, [[calorie]]s and sugars of a normal Pepsi, and is sweetened with [[Splenda]]. Introduced in 2004, and discontinued in 2005. It was featured on an episode of ''[[The Apprentice (US Season 2)|The Apprentice 2]]'' in which teams had to design a prototype bottle. **'''Pepsi Avantage''': the French name for Pepsi Edge, sold exclusively during 2005 in [[Quebec]], [[Canada]]. *'''Diet Pepsi Free''' (now known as '''Caffeine-Free Diet Pepsi''') *'''[[Jazz (soft drink)|Pepsi Jazz]]''' flavored colas only available in diet styles. Introduced in July 2006 as Pepsi Jazz and discontinued in 2009. **'''Black Cherry French Vanilla''' **'''Strawberries and Cream''' **'''Caramel Cream''' (introduced Feb. 2007) **'''Coffee Mousse''' (introduced Feb. 2016) *'''Diet Pepsi Kona''' A coffee soda available in test markets in 1997. *'''Pepsi Kick''': Introduced in Mexico in 2009. Calorie-free Pepsi with added Caffeine and Ginseng. *'''Diet Pepsi cherry vanilla''': Pepsi cherry vanilla, but low calorie. was only available for 8 weeks in the summer of 2010. *'''Pepsi Light''': Lemon-flavored Diet Pepsi sold in the 1970s and 1980s. *'''Pepsi Light''': The name under which Diet Pepsi is currently distributed in countries outside the United States, United Kingdom, Australia and other English language countries. **'''Diet Pepsi Light''' **'''Pepsi Light Twist''' **'''Pepsi Light Lima''': Pepsi Light, but with a touch of lime. Sold only in Spain **'''Pepsi Light mojito''': Pepsi Light, but with a touch of [[mojito]] taste. Has no alcohol. Sold in Germany in 2008. *'''Diet Pepsi Lemon''': A new flavor of Diet Pepsi released in 2009. *'''Diet Pepsi Lime''': A lime-flavored diet Pepsi. Temporarily available. *'''Pepsi Twist Zero''': Available in Brazil *'''[[Diet Pepsi Max]]''': Was available in the United States and Canada. Diet Pepsi with added caffeine and ginseng. This product is not related to Pepsi Max as it has significantly different ingredients and no calories.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.bevnet.com/news/2007/02-22-2007-pepsi_max.asp |website= BevNET.com |location= Purchase, New York |title= New Invigorating Zero-Calorie Cola Hits Shelves This Summer |date= February 22, 2007 |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> Diet Pepsi Max was renamed "Pepsi Max" in late 2008 along with the redesign of Pepsi. *'''[[Pepsi Max]]''': Was only available outside the [[United States]] until the name change of Diet Pepsi Max in 2008. Pepsi with no sugar. **'''Pepsi Max Cool Lemon''': Pepsi Max with lemon available in Belgium in 2006. **'''Pepsi Max Chill''': (flavored with apple) **'''Pepsi Max Mojo''': A variation flavoured with lime and a hint of mint. Sold in Finland in 2008. **'''Pepsi Max Citron Citron Vert''' (sold in France) **'''Pepsi Max Cino''': (UK - Pepsi Max with coffee) Discontinued<ref>{{cite web|author=mcjakeqcool |url=http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/news/supermarkets-poised-to-axe-pepsi-coffee-flavoured-cola/2053225.article |title=Supermarkets poised to axe Pepsi coffee-flavoured cola |publisher=Marketing Week |date= |accessdate=2010-06-01}}</ref> **'''Pepsi Max Energy''': Pepsi Max with 66% more caffeine, flavored with ginseng. Sold in Germany in 2008. **'''Pepsi Max Gold''': Limited edition in the UK market for Christmas 2005; available September to December **'''Pepsi Max Twist''': Lemon and lime flavor available in the UK **'''Pepsi Max Mojito''': [[Mojito]] flavor available in [[Denmark]] **'''Pepsi Max Cease Fire''': With a hint of lime. It is meant to be consumed with [[Doritos]] burn, to "cool the burn". Sold in the United States, Australia, and New Zealand. In the UK, it is called Citrus Freeze. **'''Pepsi Max Punch''': A low calorie edition of Pepsi Holiday Spice. Only sold in the UK in Christmas 2005. **'''Pepsi Max Cherry''': A cherry-flavoured Pepsi Max. Released in the UK in June 2011 only at Asda stores in 2 liter bottles, as of 2012 available in other select retail stores. Also available in France as of 2014, in Denmark, Norway, and Germany as of 2015 and in Finland and Iceland as of 2016. Available in Russia since late 2017 or early 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.rayon-boissons.com/Nouveaux-Produits/Pepsi-Max-a-son-cherry-29039 |language= French |title= Pepsi Max a son cherry |trans-title= Pepsi Max has cherry |date= April 1, 2014 |publisher=Rayon Bouissons |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> **'''Pepsi Max Citrus Freeze''': A lime-flavoured Pepsi Max similar to Cease Fire. Released in the UK in October 2011 for a limited time. **'''Pepsi Max Vanilla''': A vanilla-flavoured Pepsi max available in Australia since February 2018 and in New Zealand since April 2018. **'''Pepsi Max Lime''': A lime-flavoured Pepsi max available in Denmark since January 2018, in Sweden since March 2018, in Russia and in Finland. It was available in Australia for a limited run in 2016. **'''Pepsi Max Ginger''': A Ginger-flavoured Pepsi max available in the united kingdom and since 2017 in Norway, Finland, The Netherlands, Denmark and Sweden. *'''Pepsi Max Wild Side''': "Wild baobab flavor, no sugar" flavor sold in Sweden in 2010. *'''Pepsi NEX''': A zero-calorie Pepsi available in Japan and South Korea, developed by [[Suntory]]<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.suntory.com/about/news/2006/9340.html|title=Suntory Announces Launch of "PEPSI NEX" ~ World Debut of Original Suntory PEPSI Brand ~ New Generation Cola Hits Store Shelves Refuting the idea that 'colas come from America' |website= Suntory.com |date= 19 January 2006 |accessdate= 2006-07-04}}</ref> (Also advertised through the anime ''[[Tiger & Bunny]]'' and ''[[U-Know]]'' and ''[[Changmin|Max]]'' of [[TVXQ]])<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7sD5ejwPeGA|title=Tiger & Bunny - Blue Rose's Commercial : Pepsi NEX |website= YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsworldi.segye.com/Articles/EntCulture/Article.asp?aid=20110512002791&subctg1=50&subctg2=00 |title=동방신기, '펩시 넥스' CF모델 선정 - 건강한 웃음 푸른 희망 - 스포츠월드 |trans-title= TVXQ, 'Pepsi Nex' CF model chosen |publisher=Sportsworldi.segye.com |language= Korean |date= May 12, 2011 |accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref> *'''[[Pepsi Next]]''': a mid-calorie version of Pepsi released in March 2012, described by the company as having "60% lower sugar content and fewer calories."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/greatspeculations/2012/04/09/pepsico-bubbles-to-71-by-boosting-soft-drink-sales/ |work=[[Forbes]] |title= PepsiCo Bubbles To $71 By Pumping Up Pepsi Next |first= Trefis |last= Team |date= April 9, 2012 |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> **'''Pepsi Next Cherry Vanilla'''<ref name=Marvo730>{{cite news |url=http://www.theimpulsivebuy.com/wordpress/2012/07/30/review-pepsi-next-cherry-vanilla-pepsi-next-paradise-mango/ |title= REVIEW: Pepsi Next Cherry Vanilla & Pepsi Next Paradise Mango |author= Marvo |website= TheImpulsiveBuy.com |date= July 30, 2012 |accessdate= January 10, 2016 }}</ref> **'''Pepsi Next Paradise Mango'''<ref name=Marvo730 /> *'''[[Pepsi ONE]]''': An alternative to Diet Pepsi, with one calorie per serving. It continued to use the 2003 Pepsi design until mid-2012. *'''[[Pepsi Twist|Diet Pepsi Twist]]''' **'''Diet Pepsi Kickoff''': Diet Pepsi with Lemon. To be released for the 2008 [[NFL]] season. **'''Diet Pepsi Twistão''' (see above) *'''Diet Pepsi Vanilla''': Vanilla-flavored diet soda. Pepsi's response to Diet Vanilla Coke. Temporarily available. *'''Diet Pepsi Wild Cherry''': Not widely available until 2005, when Wild Cherry Pepsi was reformulated. Now uses the 2008 Pepsi design *'''Pepsi XL''' another mid-calorie cola targeted at males, and transition consumers (those making the move from regular to diet colas). *'''Pepsi Sugar Free''': Released in November 2007. *'''Pepsi Twist 3''': Released in Brazil in 2008. It has 3 calories of the natural lemon juice. *'''[[Pepsi Zero Sugar|Pepsi Black]]''': Introduced in 2017 in Croatia, the Czech Republic, Greece, Hungary, Slovakia, Slovenia, and Ukraine. Similar but not to be confused with Pepsi Max. In Croatia, Greece, Hungary, Slovenia, and Ukraine it replaced the locally unsuccessful Pepsi Light.<ref>[http://pepsisi.lin54.host25.com/pepsi-black.html Pepsi brez sladkorjev] - Official Pepsi Slovenia - Pepsi Black</ref> *'''Diet Pepsi with Splenda''': Diet Pepsi sweetened with [[Splenda]]. First released in 2015 as a reformulation of regular Diet Pepsi, which replaced the original aspartame-sweetened formula until 2018. While no longer available for retail, it can still be purchased via [[E-commerce]].<ref>[http://www.pepsicobeveragefacts.com/Home/product?formula=F0000003519&form=RTD&size=12 Diet Pepsi with Splenda] - Official Site for PepsiCo Beverage Information | Product</ref>
==Fictional drinks== *'''Pepsi Perfect''': A vitamin-enriched Pepsi variation shown in the movie ''[[Back to the Future Part II]]'' in scenes set in the year 2015.

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} [[File:Llanymynech Hoffmann Lime kiln - geograph.org.uk - 924728.jpg|thumb|Llanymynech Hoffmann lime kiln <small>photo: Colin Lea, geograph.org.uk</small>]] [[File:Lime kilns and chimney - geograph.org.uk - 1322232.jpg|thumb|Lime kilns and chimney <small>photo: John M, geograph.org.uk</small>]] [[File:Reconstructed tramway - geograph.org.uk - 1330463.jpg|thumb|Reconstructed tramway <small>photo: John M, geograph.org.uk</small>]] [[File:Sculpture close up at Llanymynech heritage area - geograph.org.uk - 1570140.jpg|thumb|Sculpture at Llanymynech Heritage Area <small>photo: John Firth, geograph.org.uk</small>]] '''Llanymynech Heritage Area''' is an historic former [[lime kiln]], [[quarry]] and industrial site near the village of [[Llanymynech]], Shropshire in the [[Welsh Marches]]. The site is adjacent to the [[A483 road]] and close to the [[Montgomery Canal]]. It is about {{convert|6|mi|0}} south of [[Oswestry]] on the English side of the border, and about {{convert|9|mi|0}} north of the [[Powys]] town of [[Welshpool]].
== History and significance ==
This is a nationally significant industrial heritage area, containing one of only three remaining [[Hoffmann kiln]]s in the country.<ref name="shropshire">{{cite web|author=web.manager@shropshire.gov.uk |url=http://www.shropshire.gov.uk/outdoor-recreation/parks-and-countryside-sites/llanymynech-heritage-area/ |title=Llanymynech Heritage Area – Shropshire Council |publisher=Shropshire.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=4 August 2013}}</ref> It provides key insights into industrial archaeology, as it was a major centre of the [[Lime (material)|lime]] industry until the early 20th century.<ref name="shropshire" /> It is not known when the lime industry started here, but it may date back to [[medieval]] times or possibly earlier. The first reference to the site is on a map from 1753. Evidence of early settlement locally includes a prehistoric hill fort on Llanmynech HIll, while [[Offa's Dyke]] runs close to the site on the western perimeter. The area also has a long history of industrial activity, including copper and lead mining dating back to at least the [[Roman Britain|Roman period]].<ref name="cpat">{{cite web|url=http://www.cpat.org.uk/projects/longer/llanymyn/llanym.htm |title=Clwyd-Powys Archaeological Trust – Projects – Recent projects – Llanymynech |publisher=Cpat.org.uk |date= |accessdate=4 August 2013}}</ref>
== Description of the site ==
Prior to the opening of the Montgomery Canal (then known as the [[Ellesmere Canal]]) in 1796, limestone quarrying was undertaken on the site on a relatively small scale, although lime kilns for lime burning appear to have been within the quarry from at least 1753. In 1806 a tramway and incline was constructed to transport limestone from the quarry to a new wharf on the canal. A second tramway was constructed to the east of the site sometime between 1807–1837 and this became the main transport route, remaining in use until the closure of the quarry in 1914.<ref name="cpat" />
The 1863 opening of the [[Llanfyllin branch]] line, part of [[Cambrian Railways]], had a major impact on the quarry, enabling much faster transportation of limestone and opening up new potential markets. Additional track and sidings were built along with two [[Lime_kiln#Types_of_kiln|draw kilns]] – located to the west of the Hoffman kiln. Designed for continuous operation and built after 1874, these two kilns were abandoned by 1900.<ref name="cpat" />
The Hoffman kiln was the last major development on the site and is believed to have been built around 1900, along with additional tramways and rail track. The kiln, which is exceptionally well preserved, measures around {{convert|44.8|xx|17.5|m|ft}} and has two tunnel vaults entered through 14 round-headed arches. The chimney, a local landmark, stands on a plinth and is around {{convert|42.5|m|0}} high.<ref name="cpat" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/daysout/grant-aided-properties/hoffman-kiln-chimney-and-draw-kiln-llanymynech-sy22-6jx/ |title=Hoffman Kiln Chimney and Draw Kiln, Llanymynech |publisher=English Heritage |date=12 February 2013 |accessdate=4 August 2013}}</ref>
== Restoration and community project ==
A restoration project ran from 2006–2009, with funding from both the Heritage Lottery Fund and [[English Heritage]]. Additional financial support also came from the Aggregates Levy Sustainability Fund and project partners, with the aim to conserve the site for visitors and educational purposes.<ref name="shropshire" />
As part of the project, an archaeological investigation was carried out.<ref name="invest"> Discovering Shropshire's History [http://www.shropshirehistory.org.uk/html/search/verb/GetRecord/theme:20091009142647 "Archaeological investigations at the Llanymynech Limeworks Heritage Site in 2006-7"] Date retrieved: 1 August 2013 </ref> Its main aim was to gather information about key features of the site – particularly the location of former tramways, ground surfaces and turntable track-beds.<ref name="invest"/>
A local community project also received funding from the [[Heritage Lottery Fund]], highlighting the importance of the area through initiatives including: * Commissioning a sculpture, information boards, signage and leaflets * Providing picnic benches and seating * Volunteer research visit, wharf clearance, tours and opening of the canalside stable block. * Creating a website and producing a social history archive.<ref name="heritage">Llanymynech Community Project [http://www.llanymynech.org.uk/html/community_project.html "Community Project"]. Date retrieved: 1 August 2013 </ref> == Artefacts from the site ==
Some artefacts discovered at the site in recent years are on display at Oswestry Town Museum. These range from tools and a quarryman's boot to a tramway [[Railroad tie|sleeper]], [[Railway coupling|couplings]] and a [[Pulley|pulley wheel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oswestrytownmuseum.co.uk/index.php/exploring-the-museum/llanymynech-limeworks/ |title=Llanymynech Limeworks |publisher=Oswestry Town Museum |date=20 June 2012 |accessdate=4 August 2013}}</ref>
== Walking Activities == This area contains a variety of short or long walks with routes leading passed lime kilns, woodland, canals, old railways, and grazed pastures.<ref name="shropshire"/> Along these routes are various information panels and sculptures to inform you about the area, some of these pathways are rough and so suitable footwear is recommended.<ref name="shropshire"/>
== References ==
{{reflist}}
== External links ==
*[http://shropshire.gov.uk/media/261689/llanymynech-conservation-plan.pdf Conservation plan from Shropshire County Council (PDF)] *[http://www.llanymynech.org.uk/ Llanmynech Community Project website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120417091001/http://www.nationaltrail.co.uk/OffasDyke/uploads/hoffman-hike.pdf National Trail 'Hoffman Hike' walking route (PDF)]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox accounting body |image = MIA logo.jpg |image_border = |alt = |image_caption = |abbreviation = MIA |motto = Accountants: Managers of Value |predecessor = <!-- Name of any predecessor entity if any --> |formation = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|1967|01|01}} |legal_status = [[Body corporate]] incorporated under the Accountants Act, 1967 of the [[Parliament of Malaysia]] |objective = Regulate and develop the accounting profession in [[Malaysia]] |headquarters = [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia |coords = |region_served = [[Malaysia]] |membership_num = 34947 members (as of 18 July 2018) |students_num = <!-- No of students --> |members_designations = C.A.(M), L.A.(M) or A.M.(M) |language = English and Malay |highest_officer_title = President |highest_officer_name = Salihin Abang |second_officer_title = Vice-President |second_officer_name = Dato' Narendra Kumar Jasani |third_officer_title = Chief Executive Officer |third_officer_name = Dr Nurmazilah Dato' Mahzan ||administering_organ = Council |IFAC_membership_date = 7 October 1977 |additional_data_name1 = |additional_data1 = |additional_data_name2 = |additional_data2 = |additional_data_name3 = |additional_data3 = |num_staff = |website = {{URL|http://www.mia.org.my}} |remarks = }}
'''Malaysian Institute of Accountants''' ('''MIA''') is the umbrella body for the [[accountancy]] profession in [[Malaysia]]. It was established under the Accountants Act, 1967 to regulate and develop the accountancy profession in this country. MIA operates under the purview of the [[Ministry of Finance (Malaysia)|Ministry of Finance]] through the Accountant General's Department.
MIA is the only accountancy body empowered by law to [[regulation|regulate]] the accountancy profession in Malaysia, thus making MIA membership mandatory for those holding themselves out or practising as an [[accountant]] in the country. MIA’s membership encompasses both legal and market recognition for accountants in Malaysia.
Members of MIA are conferred with the designation Chartered Accountant Malaysia, abbreviated as `C.A.(M)’. This designation is given to a professional in accountancy, business and finance with recognised accountancy qualification and relevant work experience. At present, there are more than 34,500 MIA members working in all industries and states of Malaysia.
As an umbrella body for all the accountants in Malaysia, MIA’s responsibilities include education and quality assurance as well as enforcement, to maintain the credibility of the profession and the public interest.<ref>{{cite web|title=About MIA|url=https://www.mia.org.my/v2/discover-mia/discover-mia.aspx|accessdate=18 July 2018}}</ref> MIA is a member of the [[International Federation of Accountants]] (IFAC)<ref>{{cite web|title=Members|url=http://www.ifac.org/about-ifac/membership/members?letter=M|publisher=IFAC|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> and the [[ASEAN Federation of Accountants]] (AFA).<ref>{{cite web|title=Membership|url=http://www.aseanaccountants.org/abo_membership.htm|publisher=AFA|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref>
MIA hosted the 18th [[World Congress of Accountants]] from 8–11 November 2010, which was held at the [[Kuala Lumpur Convention Centre]]. A record number of 6,000 delegates from 134 countries participated. The Congress, which originated in 1904 and has been held regularly since 1977, was jointly organised by the MIA and the [[International Federation of Accountants]] (IFAC).<ref>[http://www.ifac.org/news-events/2010-11/world-congress-accountants-2010-opens-record-number-delegates World Congress of Accountants 2010 Opens with Record Number of Delegates], IFAC. 8 November 2010. Retrieved 15 January 2014.</ref>
==Presidents of MIA== The President is elected among the members of MIA Council. Among those who served as President are: * Dato' Shamsir Omar (1967–87) * Dato' Hanifah Noordin (1987–99) * Dato' Syed Amin Aljeffri (2000) * Tan Sri Abdul Samad Hj. Alias (2000–05) * Abdul Rahim Abdul Hamid (2005–07) * Nik Mohd Hasyudeen Yusoff (2007–09) * Abdul Rahim Abdul Hamid (2009–11) * Datuk Mohd Nasir Ahmad (2011–13) * Datuk Johan Idris (2013–15) * Dato' Mohammad Faiz Azmi (2015–17) * Salihin Abang (2017–Present)
==See also== * [[Accountancy in Malaysia]]
==References== <references />
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.mia.org.my}} * [http://www.micpa.com.my/ Malaysian Institute of Certified Public Accountants] * [http://www.maref.org.my/ Malaysian Accountancy Research and Education Foundation]

McCormick.jpg | width5 = | alt5 = | caption5 = [[Leander J. McCormick|Leander James McCormick]] (1819–1900) | image6 =Joseph Medill McCormick 1912.jpg | width6 = | alt6 = | caption6 = [[Joseph M. McCormick|Joseph Medill McCormick]] (1877–1925) | image7 = Robert R. McCormick cph.3b30054.jpg | width7 = | alt7 = | caption7 = [[Robert R. McCormick|Robert Rutherford McCormick]] (1880–1955) }} The '''McCormick family''' of [[Chicago]] and [[Virginia]] is an [[Americans|American]] family of [[Ulster Scots people|Scots-Irish]] descent that attained prominence and fortune starting with the invention of the McCormick [[Reaper]] a machine that revolutionized [[agriculture]], helped break the bonds of [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]], and established the modern [[grain trade]] by beginning the [[mechanised agriculture|mechanization]] of the [[harvest]]ing of [[grain]]. Through the McCormick Harvesting Machine Company and later, the [[International Harvester|International Harvester Company]] and other investments, the McCormicks became one of the wealthiest families in America. The name became ubiquitous in agriculture starting in the 19th century and the press dubbed the McCormicks the "Reaper Kings". Later generations expanded into [[media (communication)|media]] and [[publishing]] ([[Tribune Media|Tribune Company]]), [[finance]] ([[William Blair & Company]]), and [[real estate]] (McCormick Estate). Various family members were well known as [[civic engagement|civic leaders]]. They are descended from an influential leader of modern agriculture, inventor [[Robert McCormick (Virginia)|Robert McCormick Jr.]] (1780–1846), and Mary Ann "Polly" Hall of [[Steeles Tavern, Virginia]]. ==Family members== Three branches: (1) Cyrus-the McCormick Blaines and the Rockefeller McCormicks. (2) William-the Deering McCormicks, the Medill McCormicks, and the McCormick Blairs. (3) Leander-the Hall McCormicks, the McCormick-Goodharts, and the Hamilton McCormicks. [[Robert McCormick (Virginia)|Robert McCormick Jr.]] (1780–1846) was an American inventor who lived in rural Virginia. In 1808 he married Mary Ann "Polly" Hall (1780–1853). They had five surviving children. * [[Cyrus McCormick|Cyrus Hall McCormick Sr.]] (1809–1884), m. [[Nancy Fowler McCormick]] (1835-1923). Entrepreneur, publisher, father of modern agriculture, and founder of what became the International Harvester Company. At a young age he improved and later patented his father's mechanical reaper. He and his brother and sisters moved to Chicago in 1847. He was a candidate for U.S. Representative from [[Illinois]] in 1862. A devout Presbyterian, he was the primary benefactor of the [[McCormick Theological Seminary]].[http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/mccormick.html#1HX065DY1 The Political Graveyard: Index to Politicians: Mccormic to Mccormick] ** [[Cyrus McCormick Jr.|Cyrus Hall McCormick Jr.]] (1859–1936), head of International Harvester. A music lover, he brought [[Sergei Prokofiev]] to the United States. In 1923, he and his mother donated McCormick Hall to Princeton University. A member of the Jekyll Island Club, a founder of the Chicago Community Trust, and a financier of the [[World's Columbian Exposition]]. He had three children: Cyrus III (who wrote ''The Century of the Reaper''),{{Harvnb|McCormick|1931}}. Elizabeth (who died in infancy), and Gordon. He had no grandchildren. ** Mary Virginia McCormick (1861-1941) never married or had any children. Her family had her declared mentally incompetent at the age of nineteen.[http://digital.library.wisc.edu/1711.dl/wiarchives.uw-whs-mcc0001d] Mary Virginia McCormick Papers, Wisconsin Historical Society ** [[Anita McCormick Blaine]] (1866-1954) founded the New World Foundation and also the Francis W. Parker School and the Laboratory School at the University of Chicago. Despite coming from a conservative Republican family, she embraced progressive movements, such as the [[United Nations]] and the suffragist movement. She was the grandmother of Nancy Blaine, wife of [[Gilbert A. Harrison]]; they owned ''[[The New Republic]]'' magazine. ** [[Harold Fowler McCormick|Harold Fowler McCormick Sr.]] (1872–1941), m. (1895) [[Edith Rockefeller McCormick|Edith Rockefeller]], youngest daughter of [[John D. Rockefeller|John Davison Rockefeller]] and [[Laura Spelman Rockefeller|Laura Celestia "Cettie" Spelman]]. Edith and Harold were the wealthiest couple in Chicago and were great patrons of the Civic Opera. They were major discoverers of James Joyce and Carl Jung. They built a massive estate, Villa Turicum, in Lake Forest, Illinois. Harold was a pioneer in aviation, running a number of successful flights, and donated the Harold F. McCormick Collection of Aeronautica at Princeton. His promotion of his wife's music career was partial inspiration for [[Charles Foster Kane]] in the movie ''[[Citizen Kane]]''.http://www.wga.org/subpage_newsevents.aspx?id=1908 *** John Rockefeller McCormick (1896–1901) *** Editha McCormick (1897–1898) *** Harold Fowler McCormick Jr. (1898–1973), m. (1931) Anne "Fifi" Potter (1879–1969). *** Muriel McCormick (1902–1959), m. (1931) Elisha Dyer Hubbard (1878-1936). *** Mathilde McCormick (1905–1947), m. (1923) Max Oser (1877–1942). **** Anita Oser Pauling (d. 2009 in Paris, France) m. Peter Max Oser (d. 1970 in Geneva, Switzerland). :* Stanley Robert McCormick (1874-1947), m. (1904) [[Katharine Dexter McCormick]] (1875–1967). Katharine, one of the earliest female graduates of MIT, was a suffragist, worked with [[Margaret Sanger]] and funded the invention of birth control using interest earned from International Harvester dividends. Stanley, a champion tennis player at Princeton, met Katharine while motoring through Pride's Crossing, Massachusetts. He later became a recluse at Riven Rock, one of the great estates of Santa Barbara, California, the subject of which was turned into a novel by T.C. Boyle. * [[William Sanderson McCormick]] (1815–1865), inventor and co-founder of the McCormick Harvesting Machine Company (International Harvester). Third son of Robert Jr. and Polly. In support of his native Virginia, he was known for wearing a Confederate uniform well after the Civil War. ** [[Robert Sanderson McCormick]] (1849–1919), U.S. Minister to [[Austria-Hungary]] 1901–1902, U.S. Ambassador to Austria-Hungary 1902, U.S. Ambassador to [[Russia]] 1902–1905, U.S. Ambassador to [[France]] 1905–1907. He built the [[McCormick House (Washington, D.C.)|McCormick Villa]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], now the Brazilian Embassy. Robert Sanderson McCormick was also the son-in-law of [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] Mayor [[Joseph Medill]] and Katherine Patrick.[http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/meagher-meek.html#RLX19E342 The Political Graveyard: Index to Politicians: Meaghan to Meek][http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/patterson.html#1HX092BR4 The Political Graveyard: Index to Politicians: Patterson] *** [[Joseph M. McCormick|Joseph Medill McCormick]] "Medill" (1877–1925), married [[Ruth Hanna McCormick|Ruth Hanna]] (1880-1944). He was a delegate to the Republican National Convention in 1916 and 1920, member of the Illinois Legislature, U.S. Representative from Illinois 1917–1919, and U.S. Senator from Illinois 1919–1925.[http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=M000369 McCORMICK, Joseph Medill - Biographical Information] Ruth was a Republican National Committeewoman 1924-1928, U.S. Representative from Illinois 1929–1931, and nominee for the U.S. Senate from Illinois in 1930.[http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=M000372 McCORMICK, Ruth Hanna - Biographical Information] She maintained a large farm in Byron, Illinois. Ruth Hanna McCormick was also the daughter of U.S. Senator [[Mark Hanna]] and Charlotte Augusta Rhodes,[http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=H000163 HANNA, Marcus Alonzo (Mark) - Biographical Information] and later wife of U.S. Representative [[Albert G. Simms]][http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=S000420 SIMMS, Albert Gallatin - Biographical Information] after Medill McCormick's death. **** Katrine McCormick **** John Medill "Johnny" McCormick **** [[Bazy Tankersley|Ruth "Bazy" McCormick Miller Tankersley]] (1921-2013) *** [[Robert R. McCormick|Robert Rutherford "Bertie" McCormick]] (1880–1955), famous publisher of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' and patriarch of Chicago. He was a delegate to the Republican National Convention in 1912, 1940, 1948 and 1952. He married twice and died childless. He considered his favorite niece, Ruth "Bazy" McCormick, to be his heir.{{cite web|last=Bernstein |first=Adam |url=https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-02-06/local/36948065_1_publisher-washington-times-herald-chicago-tribune |title=Ruth Tankersley, Tribune scion, D.C. publisher and Arabian horse breeder, dies|work=Washington Post |publisher=Articles.washingtonpost.com |date=2013-02-06 |accessdate=2013-03-25}} Upon his death his estate became the Robert R. McCormick Foundation. McCormick Place is named for him as is the McCormick School of Engineering at Northwestern University. His estate, [[Cantigny]] in Wheaton, Illinois, is now a museum. ([[Joseph Medill Patterson]] (1879–1946), Illinois State Representative in 1903, was first cousin of J. Medill McCormick and Robert Rutherford McCormick through the Medill family.) :* [[William Grigsby McCormick]] (1851-1941), Chicago businessman. Founded Kappa Sigma Fraternity at the University of Virginia. :** [[Chauncey McCormick|Chauncey Brooks McCormick]] (1884–1954), president of International Harvester. Married Marion Deering, heiress of the Deering Machine Company fortune that had merged with McCormick to form International Harvester. They owned Villa Vizcaya in Miami. :*** [[Brooks McCormick]] (1917-2006). Last McCormick to have a senior role at International Harvester; his wife [[Hope Baldwin McCormick]] (1919-1993) served in the [[Illinois House of Representatives]].'Hope Baldwin Mccormick, Civic Leader,' '''Chicago Tribune,''' Kenan Heise, July 15, 1993 :*** Roger McCormick :*** Charles Deering McCormick :* Anna Reubenia "Ruby" McCormick (1860-1917), m. Edward T. Blair (1857-1939), hardware tycoon, and commissioned McKim, Meade, & White to build what is one of the last standing homes on Lake Shore Drive in Chicago. :** [[William M. Blair|William McCormick Blair Sr.]] (1884–1982), founder of William Blair & Co. (which specialized in financing homes in the Midwest). Married Helen Hadduck Bowen (1890-1972), daughter of Joseph Tilton Bowen and Louise deKoven. :*** Helen Bowen Blair :*** Edward McCormick Blair (1915-2010) :*** [[William McCormick Blair Jr.]] (1916-2015). Investment banker, U.S. Ambassador to [[Denmark]] 1961–1964, U.S. Ambassador to the [[Philippines]] 1964–1967. :*** Bowen Blair (1918-2009) :** Lucy McCormick Blair Linn (1886-1978), well-known Chicago socialite. * [[Leander J. McCormick]] (1819–1900). Inventor and co-founder of the McCormick Harvesting Machine Company, he owned vast tracts of land in downtown Chicago and Lake Forest, Illinois. In the 1880s, he donated the McCormick Observatory to the University of Virginia in an effort to help the South recover from the war. At the time it was the second largest telescope in the world and the largest in America. Upon his death, his vast real estate holdings became the Leander J. McCormick Estate. Leander married Henrietta Maria Hamilton (1822-1899) of Virginia, a direct descendant of the Dukes of Hamilton of Scotland, heirs to the Scottish throne. ** Robert Hall McCormick II (1847–1917), m. Sarah Lord Day (1850-1922). Head of the McCormick Estate, he built the McCormick Building and Roanoke building in downtown Chicago, among others. His chief interests were horses, yachting, and art. He owned one of the finest collections of British master paintings in the United States. With Bertha Palmer he exhibited some of his paintings at the World's Columbian Exposition in 1893 and was a trustee of the Art Institute of Chicago. He owned two steam yachts: the ''Rapidan'', which was wrecked in Delaware, and the ''Satilla,'' named after a river near the Jekyll Island Club and which became a naval ship during World War II. Sarah was the daughter and granddaughter of founders of the law firm [[Lord Day & Lord]]. *** Elizabeth Day McCormick (1873-1957) owned one of the finest and most complete textile and costume collections, now the Elizabeth Day McCormick Collection at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. To the University of Chicago she donated two very important early Greek texts, the Rockefeller-McCormick Manuscript, in memory of her cousin and fellow collector, Edith Rockefeller McCormick, and later the Elizabeth Day McCormick Apocalypse. *** Robert Hall McCormick III (1878-1963). Head of the McCormick Estate and Alderman for Chicago's 21st Ward, and worked as a secretary to the Brazilian Ambassador in Rio de Janeiro. Welcomed [[Guglielmo Marconi]] to the U.S. in 1914. Maintained a Roman-style sailing ship, the ''San Marco'', in Venice, Italy, which was sunk by the Nazis during World War II. He built the Apollo Theater and was director of the Civic Opera after the death of Harold McCormick. He married Eleanor Russell Morris (1881-1970), descended from the Lords of the Manor of Morrisania, owners of the South Bronx and founders of New Jersey. Her ancestors include Lewis Morris, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, and Gouverneur Morris, the penman of the U.S. Constitution.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} ** Henrietta Laura McCormick-Goodhart (1857–1932). One of the first American heiresses to marry an English aristocrat, she lived in England and, later, at her estate, Langley Park in Maryland. By order of Queen Victoria, her last name was officially changed to encompass her husband's name, Goodhart. She had two sons, Leander and Frederick. Leander was a main figure at the British Embassy in Washington, D.C. ** [[L. Hamilton McCormick|Leander Hamilton McCormick]] (1859–1934), art collector and inventor. He is credited with the creation of the study of characterology. He had three sons: Leander James McCormick II, Edward Hamilton McCormick, and Alister Hamilton McCormick (1891–1921). Alister married Joan Tyndale Stevens, a niece of Charles Morton Astley, Lord Hastings. Leander II married the Comtesse de Fontarce et Flueries.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} {{McCormick Chicago family tree}} ==Legacy== The McCormicks are remembered through their philanthropy and projects named in their honor, including: *[[McCormick Place]] *[[Art Institute of Chicago]] *[[Fourth Presbyterian Church (Chicago)|Fourth Presbyterian Church, Chicago]] *[[University of Chicago]] *McCormick Hospital, Thailand *[[McCormick Theological Seminary]] *McCormick Hall, Princeton University *McCormick Farm, Virginia Tech *McCormick Courtyard, [[Art Institute of Chicago]] *[[McCormick Observatory]], University of Virginia *Stanley McCormick Hall, MIT *[[Robert R. McCormick School of Engineering and Applied Science|McCormick School of Engineering]], Northwestern University *McCormick Library, [[Washington & Lee University]] *Chauncey and Marion Deering McCormick Foundation *Elizabeth Day McCormick Collection, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston *McCormick County, South Carolina *[[Villa Vizcaya]], Miami *McCormick Library, Groton School *Francis W. Parker School *[[Laboratory School]], University of Chicago *[[Near North Side, Chicago|McCormickville neighborhood]], Chicago *Robert R. [[McCormick Foundation]] *[[New World Foundation]] *[[Roanoke Building]] *[[Saint Barnabas on the Desert]], Paradise Valley, Arizona *[[Historic Michigan Boulevard District#Buildings in the District|McCormick Building]] 332 S. Michigan Ave., Chicago *[[McCormick Wilderness]], Baraga County, Michigan *[[Brookfield Zoo]] *Chicago History Museum *Rush University Hospital *United Artists Theater, Chicago *McCormick Boulevard, Chicago *McCormick Bridgehouse and Chicago River Museum ==Residences== *Walnut Grove, Raphine, Va. *Villa Turicum, Lake Forest, Ill. *Walden, Lake Forest, Ill. *House-in-the-Woods, Lake Forest, Ill. *[[Cantigny]], Wheaton, Ill. *Langley Hall, Langley Park, Md. *[[Villa Vizcaya]], Miami, Fla. *Crabtree Farm, Lake Forest, Ill. *[[Castle Hill (Virginia)]], Keswick, Va. *Clayton Lodge, Richfield Springs, N.Y. *[[Kildare–McCormick House|Kildare]], Huntsville, Ala. *St. James Farm, Wheaton, Ill. *[[Lotusland]], Montecito, Calif. *Eastpoint, Seal Harbor, Maine *Stanwood, Bar Harbor, Maine *McCormick Farm, Steger, Ill. *Mizzentop, Bar Harbor, Maine *Burnmouth, Bar Harbor, Maine *Gordon Hall, Dexter, Mich. *Riven Rock, Santa Barbera, Calif. *McCormick Apartments, (Andrew Mellon Building), Washington, D.C. *McCormick Villa, 3000 Massachusetts Ave., Washington, D.C. (Embassy of Brazil) *675 Rush St, Chicago *660 Rush St, Chicago *1000 Lake Shore Drive, Chicago *101 East Erie St, Chicago *50 East Huron St, Chicago *100 East Ontario St, Chicago (Lawry's Prime Rib) *Cable-McCormick mansion, 25 East Erie St., Chicago *Patterson-McCormick mansion, Astor St., Chicago *[[McCormick Ranch]], Scottsdale, Ariz. ==See also== *[[List of United States political families]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * {{Citation |last=McCormick |first=Cyrus Hall III |year=1931 |title=The Century of the Reaper |publisher=Houghton Mifflin |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jryrMgEACAAJ |lccn=31009940 |oclc=559717 |postscript=''A history monograph by Cyrus Hall McCormick III at the centennial of the reaper.''}} ==External links== * [http://www.newberry.org/collections/FindingAids/mccormickfamily/McCormickFamily.html McCormick Family Financial Records] at [[the Newberry Library]] {{DEFAULTSORT:McCormick Family}} [[Category:Political families of the United States]] [[Category:McCormick family]]

{{Infobox person | name = Mikail O. Shishkhanov | image = | caption = Mikail O. Shishkhanov | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972|8|6}} | birth_place = [[Grozny]], [[Russia]] | occupation = * Chairman of the Board of Directors of [[B&N Bank]] * Chairman of the Management Board of MDM Bank | alma_mater = Peoples’ Friendship University named after Patrice Lumumba | website = [http://eng.new.binbank.ru/board/bio/shishkhanov.php B&N Bank] }}
'''Mikail O. Shishkhanov''' is a Russian businessman and financier.
Shishkhanov is the majority shareholder (59, 4%) <ref>[http://eng.new.binbank.ru/about/shareholders/ List of Shareholders of B&N BANK]</ref> of [[B&N Bank|B&N Bank (Public Joint-Stock Company)]] and the co-owner of the B&N non-state pension capital fund “SAFMAR” (100% affiliated with B&N Bank), European pension fund, private pension fund “Doverie”, private pension fund “Obrazovanie i nauka” and private pension fund “Regionfond”) jointly with the members of Gutseriev family.
Shishkhanov is also the co-owner of the leading development companies ([http://inteco.ru/ INTECO Russian corporate site], Private joint-stock company “Patriot” (total shareholding is 95%) and, Joint-stock company “Mospromstroy”).
==Early life and education== Mikail Shishkhanov was born on August 6, 1972 in Grozny (capital city of the Chechen Republic, Russia). In 1995 he graduated from [[Peoples' Friendship University of Russia|Peoples’ Friendship University named after Patrice Lumumba]] with a master's degree in economics and law and in 2000 - Finance Academy under the Government of the Russian Federation. Shishkhanov is a Doctor of Economics, Ph.D. in law, Associate Member of the Russian Academy of Natural Sciences, Chechen.
==Business career== Since 1992, Mikail Shishkhanov has combined his study with work for B&N Industrial and Financial Company. During a short period of time, he took the position of General Director. In 1994, he joined B&N Bank where he held various positions from the Head of Interbank Relations Department to the Vice President and Deputy CEO. Shishkhanov has been President and CEO of B&N Bank since January 1996 to July 2015. Today Shishkhanov is the Chairman of the Board of Directors of B&N Bank and the Chairman of the Management Board of MDM Bank. Shishkhanov is an active participant in the banking community: Member of the Board of Russian Bankers’ Association and Moscow Banking Union. Shishkhanov is the author of two monographies and a set of books in economics and law.
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://inteco.ru/ INTECO Russian corporate site]
